description: Office 365 is a cloud based productivity suite for individuals, companies and even government agencies.  It is designed to deliver software as service to any and every user regardless of location. The Office 365 solution is designed to relieve the technical challenge of software management and delivery, regardless of location from the local IT personnel.  This allows the IT professional to focus in implementing, deploying and operating Office 365 services and administrating supporting technologies, like email, collaboration and storage.  If youâ€™re an IT professional who takes part in evaluating, planning, deploying, and operating the Office 365 services, including its dependencies, requirements, and supporting technologies this series will demonstrate and help you to see what is involved in setting up Office 365 for your organization.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel help you get started with Office365 by showing you how to set up a trial Office365 account. They explain how to provision a Tenant account, configuring the name and region, as well as describing some of the common missteps to be avoided when setting up the account. Then they configure a global administrator account which will be used to manage tenant subscriptions and the licensing.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain how to connect your Office365 account to a custom domain. They begin by going over some Domain Name System(DNS) fundamentals. This includes DNS record types, hosting, and registration. Then they show you step-by-step how to get Office365 to verify and utilize your hosted DNS solution.

00:26:24.850 --> 00:26:27.560
if they're on the other side of the
network they get a different address okay?

488
00:26:27.560 --> 00:26:32.800
If you're gonna set this up so
that Office 365 works in this situation,

489
00:26:32.800 --> 00:26:36.750
you're gonna need to create those
records on both the internal server

490
00:26:36.750 --> 00:26:39.880
as well as where on
the external records too.

491
00:26:39.880 --> 00:26:45.820
So that again is another kind of stickler,
right, for those of you that are preparing

492
00:26:45.820 --> 00:26:49.670
for an exam, that you may get a question
or two on something like this,

493
00:26:49.670 --> 00:26:52.470
like where is it actually appropriate
to do something like this.

494
00:26:52.470 --> 00:26:57.430
You got to kind of be aware that
sometimes, and we were talking about this,

495
00:26:57.430 --> 00:27:00.930
it's not so
much that it's an Office 365 issue,

496
00:27:00.930 --> 00:27:03.950
this just an issue that
the way DNS records work.

497
00:27:03.950 --> 00:27:08.400
But I want Office 365 to work so that
when people connect in from the outside,

498
00:27:08.400 --> 00:27:13.100
Daniel's checking his email cuz he's out
in Tennessee, it's going to hit here,

499
00:27:13.100 --> 00:27:16.100
and then he still needs to
point in Office 365, right.

500
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:19.970
When he's internal on the inside working
on the network, he wants to go and

501
00:27:19.970 --> 00:27:21.940
check his email,
it still needs to point that way,

502
00:27:21.940 --> 00:27:24.550
but he needs to do it from
the internal DNS servers too.

503
00:27:24.550 --> 00:27:28.160
And that's why you need to set him
up on both if you're gonna do this.

504
00:27:28.160 --> 00:27:29.840
So just kind of be aware, all right?

505
00:27:29.840 --> 00:27:31.160
Now let's go ahead and set this up.

506
00:27:31.160 --> 00:27:32.570
I talked way long, but-
>> That's right,

507
00:27:32.570 --> 00:27:33.430
we're waiting with bated breath.

508
00:27:33.430 --> 00:27:35.320
>> I know.
>> We want to see it.

509
00:27:35.320 --> 00:27:36.740
>> We'll see how we do here.

510
00:27:36.740 --> 00:27:37.330
Okay?

511
00:27:37.330 --> 00:27:37.890
So here it is.

00:27:37.890 --> 00:27:39.180
We're gonna go back to the admin.

00:27:39.180 --> 00:27:42.750
Now if you don't remember that, on Office

00:27:42.750 --> 00:27:45.400

00:27:45.400 --> 00:27:49.480
that will bring you to
the Office 365 admin center.

516
00:27:49.480 --> 00:27:53.300
And if I want to be able to use this, I
need to scroll down here on the left hand

00:27:53.300 --> 00:27:57.410
side in this navigation tree
to where it says Domains.

518
00:27:57.410 --> 00:28:03.010
And then once I get in Domains,
you see the default DNS or

00:28:03.010 --> 00:28:05.578
the default domain that it
sets up right here, okay?

00:28:05.578 --> 00:28:08.930
Which is itprotvdemo.onmicrosoft.com,

00:28:08.930 --> 00:28:11.110
this is the one that's set

00:28:11.110 --> 00:28:14.540
Notice that if you have everything set

00:28:14.540 --> 00:28:18.500
you can buy your own domain from Microsoft
if you're not doing a trial account.

00:28:18.500 --> 00:28:20.040
If you're doing a trial
account it's like hey,

00:28:20.040 --> 00:28:24.580
switch on over to a paid account, and
then you can purchase a domain but

00:28:24.580 --> 00:28:27.010
it won't let you actually purchase
one from the trial account.

527
00:28:27.010 --> 00:28:30.060
But if you happen to have your
own ready like what we do,

528
00:28:30.060 --> 00:28:32.070
I just need to simply add a domain.

529
00:28:32.070 --> 00:28:33.860
And so I'll click here and

00:28:33.860 --> 00:28:38.480
I will add this domain and now we have
these three steps that we need to follow.

531
00:28:38.480 --> 00:28:42.270
Step number one is that it had to

532
00:28:42.270 --> 00:28:45.230
If not, Daniel can simply go,
no, that's my domain and

533
00:28:45.230 --> 00:28:48.210
go ahead and take that from me and
I would never know.

534
00:28:48.210 --> 00:28:50.790
Add users and then set the domain up.

535
00:28:50.790 --> 00:28:54.580
So I'm gonna follow the link at
the bottom that says getting started, and

536
00:28:54.580 --> 00:28:57.140
when I do it's gonna ask
me what's my domain.

537
00:28:57.140 --> 00:29:04.420
It's gonna be itprotvdemo.com,
and then I'm gonna click next.

538
00:29:04.420 --> 00:29:06.233
And now, it's getting the information,

539
00:29:06.233 --> 00:29:08.810
it's going out there and
it's actually taking a look at it.

540
00:29:08.810 --> 00:29:12.800
And you can see a couple of different
ways that this actually works for us.

541
00:29:12.800 --> 00:29:16.840
Only the domain owner
can update DNS records.

542
00:29:16.840 --> 00:29:19.450
So, what are they're asking me to do?
They're asking me to go ahead and

543
00:29:19.450 --> 00:29:21.800
add this text record in here.

544
00:29:21.800 --> 00:29:24.850
So, to make sure that it can verify.

545
00:29:24.850 --> 00:29:28.070
So the way that Office 365 works here,

546
00:29:28.070 --> 00:29:32.050
is that I add this record
into my hover account.

00:29:32.050 --> 00:29:36.810
And then, once I've got that, it can then
talk and verify that that record's there.

548
00:29:36.810 --> 00:29:38.530
And then we'll be ready to go.

549
00:29:38.530 --> 00:29:40.550
So the way I do that is
I go over to my hover.

550
00:29:40.550 --> 00:29:42.490
Let me see if it actually lets me copy,
though.

551
00:29:42.490 --> 00:29:44.320
I don't know if it will
let me copy everything.

552
00:29:44.320 --> 00:29:44.820
I'll try.

553
00:29:46.700 --> 00:29:48.770
Go to my hover, and here it is.

554
00:29:48.770 --> 00:29:51.490
Here is my DNS register record and

555
00:29:51.490 --> 00:29:55.410
there's all of the different records
that I have that's been set up for me.

556
00:29:55.410 --> 00:29:59.980
I simply add a new record,
and on this host name,

557
00:29:59.980 --> 00:30:02.720
I don't know if it'll let me
paste it in the way I want it to.

558
00:30:02.720 --> 00:30:06.600
Pasted the whole thing in so, let me just
paste in a little bit at a time here.

559
00:30:06.600 --> 00:30:11.460
So I know that that's the @ and this
record type is going to be a text type.

560
00:30:11.460 --> 00:30:15.880
And then I need this value, I think.

561
00:30:17.090 --> 00:30:17.590
Yep, that's the value.

562
00:30:22.130 --> 00:30:23.210
And this should be exact.

563
00:30:24.460 --> 00:30:25.840
Is what this value should be.

564
00:30:27.790 --> 00:30:29.460
>> Just ruling out the human
error equation, aren't you?

565
00:30:29.460 --> 00:30:32.740
>> Yeah, I'm trying to, but
we'll see if that actually works or

566
00:30:32.740 --> 00:30:35.580
not, make sure that I don't do that.

567
00:30:35.580 --> 00:30:38.270
Now, the one thing that mine doesn't give
me is the ability to change the ttl,

568
00:30:38.270 --> 00:30:40.210
the time to live, so

569
00:30:40.210 --> 00:30:43.750
that may take a little bit longer and
I think I'm gonna click save.

570
00:30:43.750 --> 00:30:45.810
And let's see what happens.

571
00:30:45.810 --> 00:30:50.410
And when I scroll down I see
this last record added in.

572
00:30:50.410 --> 00:30:53.910
Now, you can actually do a TXT record or

573
00:30:53.910 --> 00:30:59.150
an MX record that actually depends on
your hosted domain provider as well, so

574
00:30:59.150 --> 00:31:01.930
one of them may actually accept one and
not the other.

575
00:31:01.930 --> 00:31:03.760
Usually they accept both.

576
00:31:03.760 --> 00:31:04.850
But you only need one or the other.

577
00:31:04.850 --> 00:31:07.180
You don't actually need to
add both of them in there.

578
00:31:07.180 --> 00:31:10.690
So that's all we need to
add in from that point.

579
00:31:10.690 --> 00:31:12.035
And then I go back to that, and

580
00:31:12.035 --> 00:31:15.100
once I've added the record,
I follow the instructions through,

581
00:31:15.100 --> 00:31:18.590
and there it goes you can see at
the bottom it says it's verified it.

582
00:31:18.590 --> 00:31:23.379
We verified that you actually
own itprotvdemo.com.

583
00:31:23.379 --> 00:31:27.940
So I am gonna click next and
now it's gonna ask me,

584
00:31:27.940 --> 00:31:31.490
select the users you want to be able
to update and use this instead.

585
00:31:31.490 --> 00:31:34.120
So I want, essentially, all my users and

586
00:31:34.120 --> 00:31:37.310
I just created another one

587
00:31:37.310 --> 00:31:40.840
So instead of actually using that, and you
see where it says it's going to update it

588
00:31:40.840 --> 00:31:48.400
to itprotv.com, instead of on Microsoft,
and I now update the selected users.

589
00:31:48.400 --> 00:31:49.350
And there it is.

590
00:31:49.350 --> 00:31:51.462
So now, it's fairly easy right?

591
00:31:51.462 --> 00:31:56.509
I've gotten rid of that default domain,
now all of my DNS is actually

00:31:56.509 --> 00:32:00.960
going to be registered through

593
00:32:00.960 --> 00:32:03.110
So there it is,

00:32:03.110 --> 00:32:05.985
Now it says for

00:32:05.985 --> 00:32:10.042
let's see if I can actually sign back in,

596
00:32:10.042 --> 00:32:14.190
Go back to this portal and
let's verify, there it is.

597
00:32:14.190 --> 00:32:18.010
So it actually did sign me out,
but I'm now using my last pass and

598
00:32:18.010 --> 00:32:21.920
it is Ronald@itprotvdemo.com.

599
00:32:21.920 --> 00:32:24.418
And if I go back and
check on the admin page here.

600
00:32:29.459 --> 00:32:31.460
And I go back to domains.

601
00:32:33.640 --> 00:32:36.530
And you can see that it's
taking a bit of time for

00:32:36.530 --> 00:32:41.220
it to resolve and finish up and

603
00:32:41.220 --> 00:32:45.400
So now it's asking me do I

00:32:45.400 --> 00:32:50.800
I can continue to add in another user if I

00:32:50.800 --> 00:32:53.610
And cuz I'm actually at step
number 3 which is what I need here

00:32:53.610 --> 00:32:55.750
is the other DNS records.

00:32:55.750 --> 00:33:00.090
So if I click Next, here,

00:33:00.090 --> 00:33:04.190
it says do I wanna to transfer

00:33:04.190 --> 00:33:07.080
No, I have an existing website or

00:33:07.080 --> 00:33:11.670
This is we're actually make that decision
based on whether using that small business

00:33:11.670 --> 00:33:15.930
account, whether using the midsize
enterprise account as well, okay.

612
00:33:15.930 --> 00:33:21.280
So I'm going to leave it as is for
right now cuz I'm using the Enterprise 3.

613
00:33:21.280 --> 00:33:23.220
And then I'm gonna click Next.

614
00:33:23.220 --> 00:33:26.570
And it says here this is
what we also have to do.

00:33:26.570 --> 00:33:29.650
This is where we also decide on

00:33:29.650 --> 00:33:31.010
Now, what is this about?

617
00:33:31.010 --> 00:33:35.630
Well remember that because this is about
DNS The very fact is if I choose less

of these options, it's going to
create less records for me, okay?

00:33:39.550 --> 00:33:42.270
And those records will also
just have to be added back into

00:33:42.270 --> 00:33:44.300
hover is what will have to happen here.

00:33:44.300 --> 00:33:49.105
If I choose more, well then it will
actually create more records for me.

622
00:33:49.105 --> 00:33:51.005
So can I come back and
change this later on?

623
00:33:51.005 --> 00:33:52.285
Yes.
You can come back in and

624
00:33:52.285 --> 00:33:53.365
change this later on.

625
00:33:53.365 --> 00:33:56.445
You can go look, I really only want
to do it for the email, calendar and

00:33:56.445 --> 00:33:59.755
contacts, but not for Skype for
Business or instant messaging.

627
00:33:59.755 --> 00:34:01.385
Well then you don't
have to worry about it.

628
00:34:01.385 --> 00:34:03.185
But I can select all of them for
right now.

629
00:34:04.930 --> 00:34:06.840
And it actually has this.

630
00:34:06.840 --> 00:34:09.720
And there's even the idea
of SharePoint online.

631
00:34:09.720 --> 00:34:12.740
And so they're actually saying that's

00:34:12.740 --> 00:34:14.270

633
00:34:14.270 --> 00:34:16.220
So we are going to click Next here.

00:34:16.220 --> 00:34:18.070
And in a moment you'll see,

00:34:18.070 --> 00:34:23.340
here are the other records it really

00:34:23.340 --> 00:34:26.360
There's the MX records that

00:34:26.360 --> 00:34:30.360
here are the C name records,

00:34:30.360 --> 00:34:35.160
that are pointing to these other host

00:34:35.160 --> 00:34:38.830
Here is another one for

00:34:38.830 --> 00:34:43.420
Here's one for sip and sipfederations too,
so they're services and so

641
00:34:43.420 --> 00:34:48.600
once you add all those records back in,
your account is gonna take a few

00:34:48.600 --> 00:34:53.330
more moments or even a little bit of time

643
00:34:53.330 --> 00:34:56.290
And from that point, you can verify and

644
00:34:56.290 --> 00:35:01.050
everything should be done and ready for

645
00:35:01.050 --> 00:35:02.070
So it's the same edition.

646
00:35:02.070 --> 00:35:03.260
You don't need to see me cut and

00:35:03.260 --> 00:35:08.640
paste all these records back
into my DNS host provider.

648
00:35:08.640 --> 00:35:12.680
But that's what well essentially happen,
is that we'll finish that configuration

649
00:35:12.680 --> 00:35:16.490
and then in the end it will verify
that everything is up and ready to go.

650
00:35:16.490 --> 00:35:20.010
And that means that because I actually
set it up for the Outlook and for

651
00:35:20.010 --> 00:35:25.080
the Skype for Business, and anything else
that I think I chose something else here

652
00:35:25.080 --> 00:35:27.390
that will actually get all
those records ready for

653
00:35:27.390 --> 00:35:30.410
everything that we actually
need to get ready for.

654
00:35:30.410 --> 00:35:34.820
So it's very important that we do
understand that that is what is going to

655
00:35:34.820 --> 00:35:39.640
happen, is that it really does take
a moment for us to be able to do that, and

656
00:35:39.640 --> 00:35:43.480
once that's actually done,
now we can actually configure

657
00:35:43.480 --> 00:35:48.500
the rest of Office 365 to get
all those other services up and

658
00:35:48.500 --> 00:35:52.390
going and now ready for
us to connect right in.

659
00:35:52.390 --> 00:35:55.670
So those records, they're just gonna
go into our DNS hosting provider and

660
00:35:55.670 --> 00:35:57.340
we're off and we're ready to go.

661
00:35:57.340 --> 00:36:00.940
>> Ronnie, great job of walking us
through what could potentially be

662
00:36:00.940 --> 00:36:03.750
a very confusing piece
of the puzzle right?

663
00:36:03.750 --> 00:36:06.110
We want to get these two
things working together and

664
00:36:06.110 --> 00:36:09.420
now we know what we need to know
about DNS and now we have seen

665
00:36:09.420 --> 00:36:13.580
what we need to configure inside of Office
365 to make those things work together.

666
00:36:13.580 --> 00:36:17.710
Thank you so much, is there anything else
that we need to know as far as this goes?

667
00:36:17.710 --> 00:36:19.460
>> Not for DNS.

668
00:36:19.460 --> 00:36:22.960
Don't get me wrong,
there is many more complexities to DNS and

669

it may come back where you
have to tweak them but

670
00:36:24.840 --> 00:36:28.000
remember you can always go back and
then change them if you need to.

671
00:36:28.000 --> 00:36:32.160
But it is kinda key, right, that at
least get that initial step on the way

672
00:36:32.160 --> 00:36:35.890
if we wanna use our own
custom domain to get started.

673
00:36:35.890 --> 00:36:36.490
>> All right, Ronnie.

674
00:36:36.490 --> 00:36:38.870
Well, thank you so
much for joining us today.

675
00:36:38.870 --> 00:36:40.750
Thank you so much for watching.

676
00:36:40.750 --> 00:36:43.520
That's as far as the episode goes,
we're gonna ahead and close her down and

677
00:36:43.520 --> 00:36:44.410
call it a day.

678
00:36:44.410 --> 00:36:47.340
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

679
00:36:47.340 --> 00:36:48.100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

680
00:36:48.100 --> 00:36:49.292
>> We'll see you next time.

681
00:36:49.292 --> 00:36:55.370

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel introduce you to the concept of "planning a pilot" when deploying Office365. They explain what a pilot is (bascially a test environment for Office365) and then start walking you through the basic understanding of setting up a pilot; this includes checking readiness, setting up domains, adding users, and connecting email accounts.
episodes.title: Plan a Pilot
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.388 --> 00:00:11.781
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.781 --> 00:00:16.280
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:19.350
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.350 --> 00:00:24.260
we're continuing on with our series
on managing Office 365 identities and

5
00:00:24.260 --> 00:00:27.700
requirements and I'm so
glad I actually got that out in one shot.

6
00:00:27.700 --> 00:00:30.950
And joining me to help me with this and
to help you as well

7
00:00:30.950 --> 00:00:33.760
is none other than our good friend and
colleague, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:35.130
Ronnie, how's it going today sir?

9
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:36.470
>> It's going well today.

10
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:39.210
It's another great day to be
right here as we take a look at,

11
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:42.620
well again migrating towards Office 365.

12
00:00:42.620 --> 00:00:45.940
Companies are beginning to do this and
if your company isn't doing it,

13
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:49.820
you might see that it might be
in the future very quickly, but

14
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:53.550
there's a lot of things that have to go
into it before we can just jump onboard

15
00:00:53.550 --> 00:00:55.892
and say this is right for
every organization.

16
00:00:55.892 --> 00:01:01.010
And so one of the things that we want to
talk about here is what we call creating

17
00:01:01.010 --> 00:01:04.349
a pilot,
is what we're actually talking about.

18
00:01:04.349 --> 00:01:08.350
Now, in the past, for most organizations,
if we were to just say,

19
00:01:08.350 --> 00:01:11.790
hey, here's a new piece of software
we believe that all of our

20
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:16.570
users really are going to need, the way
that we would do it is fairly simple.

21
00:01:16.570 --> 00:01:19.850
We would create a test bed
environment essentially and

22
00:01:19.850 --> 00:01:23.090
when we did something like that, we would
actually say, all right, let me go and

23
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:26.880
hand out the software or
put them on the users' machines, and

24
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:31.300
let them kind of play around with it and
see how they like the software.

25
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:35.740
From that particular point on, there's two
things that would have happened, right?

26
00:01:35.740 --> 00:01:38.820
One, if you're actually a fairly
conscientious person and

27

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue planning a pilot for testing their Office365 deployment. They begin by showing you how to setup an Office365 trial account as well as how to select appropriate users and designate them as pilot users. They also explain how you can use a program called IdFix to help discover and remediate objects that might hinder the Office365 deployment with your on premises systems.
episodes.title: Plan a Pilot Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

Is that not only did we talk about

So, a lot of times if you're

Okay, IdFix is gonna allow us to actually

And the reason why is that over the years,

if your active directory has

There's still different attributes,

So it's not the very fact that it can't

if I know that I'm gonna be doing this in
the future, we're gonna actually make sure

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel finish with their pilot deployment by connecting the email accounts of their pilot users to Office365. They take you step-by-step through the connection process, which includes actions like verifying domain ownership, configuring Exchange Online, updating DNS records with your DNS hosting provider, and setting up email forwarding.
episodes.title: Plan a Pilot Part 3

of course at that point you test it out.

00:18:22.470 --> 00:18:27.380
You verify that email of course is

00:18:27.380 --> 00:18:31.720
an email between internal and external,
and once that's done it's ready to go.

302
00:18:31.720 --> 00:18:36.250
So they're not the most complex steps in
the world, but it is kind of a back and

00:18:36.250 --> 00:18:38.360
forth as we're first doing it, right?

304
00:18:38.360 --> 00:18:40.480
So remember that that's

00:18:40.480 --> 00:18:41.550
Exchange Server.

00:18:41.550 --> 00:18:44.150
Get that set up, that internal relay.

00:18:44.150 --> 00:18:48.930
Make sure that every pilot user then

00:18:48.930 --> 00:18:51.390
Now you can use different

00:18:51.390 --> 00:18:56.450
I just use iMap as just an example of

00:18:56.450 --> 00:19:01.030
And then for that point your DNS
registration record makes sure the SPF

record is there, make sure you already

00:19:04.360 --> 00:19:08.210

00:19:16.910 --> 00:19:21.880
that account to be able to do that, and

00:19:21.880 --> 00:19:25.960
your user to log on, you get Outlook

00:19:25.960 --> 00:19:28.260
From that point their

>> Awesome.
Now Ronny,

it sounds like what you're saying is that

00:19:43.250 --> 00:19:45.670

00:19:48.710 --> 00:19:52.550
an Exchange Server on premise or

00:19:52.550 --> 00:19:54.880
That now becomes a relay server and
Office takes over?

327
00:19:54.880 --> 00:19:55.880
>> Right.

328
00:19:55.880 --> 00:19:59.030
That's exactly what will also end up

00:19:59.030 --> 00:20:02.580
You take one of those Exchange Servers,

00:20:06.480 --> 00:20:10.980
that way instead of actually becoming

00:20:10.980 --> 00:20:14.900
So there is going to be a point in time

00:20:26.330 --> 00:20:27.920

Once you get that working, right.

00:21:07.860 --> 00:21:12.660

00:21:12.660 --> 00:21:16.970
Your pilot's set up, and

It's not that you're testing

This one a little more complicated as

If you already set up your domain it

Make sure everything's working at the end,

00:22:13.440 --> 00:22:14.090

Well, obviously it was a lot of fun to

We thank you guys so much for watching.

Thank you for joining us, Ronny.

00:22:37.020 --> 00:22:38.710

00:22:38.710 --> 00:22:40.081

00:22:40.993 --> 00:22:42.278

378
00:22:42.278 --> 00:22:48.420
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel finish up their discussion on planning a pilot for Office365 deployment by explaining the test planning phase. Creating a test plan will involve making sure that your environment is prepared for integration with Office365, so Daniel and Ronnie make sure to introduce you to the fastrack tool from Microsoft which helps you determine that fact. They also discuss systems that might not require migration and finally go over aspects of all the Office365 service descriptions.
episodes.title: Plan a Pilot Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain how to configure your clients to connect to your Office365 service. Here they discuss and demonstrate moving ownership of DNS to Office365 and creating DNS records for the services. They also show you how to work around or with a Proxy server as well as what is necessary information for firewall exceptions. Lastly they cover best practices with regards to bandwidth and internet connectivity.
episodes.title: Enable Client Connectivity

00:36:22.140 --> 00:36:25.330
What one of the options might be here,
and how do you know that?

644
00:36:25.330 --> 00:36:29.080
Well, being able to work through
this basic mathematical process

645
00:36:29.080 --> 00:36:31.350
might let you know,
yes it's an issue with that,

646
00:36:31.350 --> 00:36:35.960
it's an issue with not enough public IP
addresses that will get you connected in.

647
00:36:35.960 --> 00:36:39.870
So we're not talking about trying to
divide up each particular megabit

648
00:36:39.870 --> 00:36:43.520
connection, but we're really talking
about some very practical stuff here.

649
00:36:43.520 --> 00:36:46.930
Even with NAP because that's what most of
us will actually be buying that we have

650
00:36:46.930 --> 00:36:50.390
some issues that we have to deal with,
especially when connecting to Office 365.

651
00:36:50.390 --> 00:36:53.420
>> So make sure you tattoo this
formula on your forearm, so

652
00:36:53.420 --> 00:36:55.970
when you go into the exam
they kick you right out.

653
00:36:55.970 --> 00:36:58.620
[LAUGH] No, that's not, but
you do want to memorize it.

654
00:36:58.620 --> 00:37:02.960
You do want to have it at least some
level of mastery with it that you know

655
00:37:02.960 --> 00:37:06.460
the concept behind it and what they're
trying to convey, so that when you go

656
00:37:06.460 --> 00:37:10.220
into the testing booth, you're not gonna
go what does all this math business.

657
00:37:10.220 --> 00:37:13.030
Ronnie has done a great job of
showing you exactly what they're

658
00:37:13.030 --> 00:37:13.780
gonna expect from you.

659
00:37:13.780 --> 00:37:16.160
Ronnie is there anything else
we need to cover before we go?

660
00:37:16.160 --> 00:37:17.050
>> Not really, right?

661
00:37:17.050 --> 00:37:21.180
The very fact is there some other
connectivity issues that have to do with

662
00:37:21.180 --> 00:37:24.120
other things like active directory and
rights management, and

663
00:37:24.120 --> 00:37:25.100
some different stuff.

664
00:37:25.100 --> 00:37:27.950
But it's not actually just
basic connectivity here.

665
00:37:27.950 --> 00:37:30.380
It's about the entire organization
getting connected and

666
00:37:30.380 --> 00:37:32.150
providing the services that we need.

667
00:37:32.150 --> 00:37:34.090
But here's a good start for us, and

668
00:37:34.090 --> 00:37:36.050
some of the things we may have
to end up troubleshooting.

669
00:37:36.050 --> 00:37:37.100
So just be aware.

670
00:37:37.100 --> 00:37:37.620
>> Awesome.

671
00:37:37.620 --> 00:37:41.830
Thank you so much for explaining this
to us and walking through this with us,

672
00:37:41.830 --> 00:37:44.290
that we might be better prepared for
it on the exam.

673
00:37:44.290 --> 00:37:45.390
And thank you for watching.

674
00:37:45.390 --> 00:37:47.390
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

675
00:37:47.390 --> 00:37:49.290
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

676
00:37:49.290 --> 00:37:49.900
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

677
00:37:49.900 --> 00:37:51.459
>> And we'll see you next time.

678
00:37:51.459 --> 00:37:55.709
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain how to stay secure in a boundless network environment that utilizes Office365 by employing Azure Rights Management. They begin by explaining why you might need Azure RM, following that with showing you how to active Azure RM in Office365. Next they show you how to use PowerShell to import and connect Azure RM to your Office365 account.
episodes.title: Azure Rights Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.620 --> 00:00:13.801
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3
00:00:13.801 --> 00:00:16.800
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:19.850
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we're continuing on with

5
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:25.130
our managing Office 365 identities and
requirements.

6
00:00:25.130 --> 00:00:27.070
Joining me in the studio today,
you know him, you love him,

7
00:00:27.070 --> 00:00:29.190
he's our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:30.180
Ronnie, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:30.180 --> 00:00:31.030
How are you doing today, sir?

10
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:35.350
>> I am doing fine and great to be back
as we continue to take a look at, well,

11
00:00:35.350 --> 00:00:38.700
really about the idea
of managing Office 365.

12
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:43.260
And today we're heading into
that unusual realm of security

13
00:00:43.260 --> 00:00:45.150
when we start dealing with cloud services.

14
00:00:45.150 --> 00:00:46.810
Now I say unusual and

15
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:52.300
the reason why is that security at one
point in my IT career was relatively easy.

16
00:00:52.300 --> 00:00:56.790
Don't get me wrong, it got harder and
harder and harder quickly, but

17
00:00:56.790 --> 00:00:59.500
the very fact is,
at one point it was simple, right?

18
00:00:59.500 --> 00:01:04.590
The easiest way to do security in the past
was all of my narrow teshi inside of my

19
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:08.990
building, and as long as I secure the
building and keep all of my perfect old

20
00:01:08.990 --> 00:01:13.260
infrastructure in place, keep my
permissions in place, make sure my users

21
00:01:13.260 --> 00:01:16.170
have the right permissions,
then I was off and ready to go.

22
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:19.760
Now when we start thinking about that,
that sounds like a great idea.

23
00:01:19.760 --> 00:01:21.400
Why don't we do that anymore?

24
00:01:21.400 --> 00:01:26.237
And that's because the world is changing,
and the world has changed that no longer

25
00:01:26.237 --> 00:01:29.785
is our data really just
secured in the building.

26
00:01:29.785 --> 00:01:34.095
You kinda remember those days where
it was kind of like an this is great.

27
00:01:34.095 --> 00:01:36.465
Somebody needs to actually
access a secured server?

28
00:01:36.465 --> 00:01:37.185
Well, what do you do?

29
00:01:37.185 --> 00:01:39.065
You make them come in on the weekend and

30
00:01:39.065 --> 00:01:42.342
you make them use the actual computer
from inside of the building.

31
00:01:42.342 --> 00:01:46.242
You don't give them things like
VPN access or remote access in.

32
00:01:46.242 --> 00:01:49.962
You don't allow them to check things
like their email from their phone or

33
00:01:49.962 --> 00:01:55.432
to send documents from a remote
device into the network in that way.

34
00:01:55.432 --> 00:02:00.229
So today's networks have changed to the
point where what you hear today is what we

35
00:02:00.229 --> 00:02:03.544
call a boundaryless network,
or a boundless network,

36
00:02:03.544 --> 00:02:08.960
in which the walls of our network are no
longer really sufficient for protection.

37
00:02:08.960 --> 00:02:13.150
And so when we start thinking about this,
it used to be easier because all of our

38
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:18.220
services were essentially on premise, so
we could secure it in an on-premise way.

39
00:02:18.220 --> 00:02:22.860
But now that you're making that
choice to move to Office 365, well,

40
00:02:22.860 --> 00:02:27.620
now you've got multiple places that
you have to worry about the security.

41
00:02:27.620 --> 00:02:31.020
You still have to worry about
the security that's on premise.

42
00:02:31.020 --> 00:02:32.610
You still have to take care
of those things that you

43
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:34.010
normally would take care of.

44
00:02:34.010 --> 00:02:38.670
But now that you've also implemented and
started to use Office 365,

45
00:02:38.670 --> 00:02:43.770
your data is now split between
where it might have began,

46
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:45.820
here it is I'm working on my workstation.

47
00:02:45.820 --> 00:02:51.140
But when I go and store it and save it,
well, now I'm actually saving it

48
00:02:51.140 --> 00:02:56.860
inside of my Office 365,
my OneDrive storage device out there.

49
00:02:56.860 --> 00:02:59.900
So Daniel,
how many people do you know that work for

50
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:01.940
let's say OneDrive over at Microsoft?

51
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:05.730
>> I know, let me see, carry the three,
yeah, zero people that work for OneDrive.

52
00:03:05.730 --> 00:03:08.700
>> So if I were to say that would you
trust the security there, you would

53
00:03:08.700 --> 00:03:13.200
obviously say absolutely, because I know
six or seven people that work there.

54
00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:16.510
Most of us, I'm not gonna say
everybody that's watching, but

55
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:20.350
most of us probably say, no, I really
don't know anybody over at OneDrive.

56
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:22.610
And I'm not just picking on OneDrive.

57
00:03:22.610 --> 00:03:27.100
Any of those cloud storage providers
that have their data stored up there

58
00:03:27.100 --> 00:03:30.830
in the cloud solution, I'm not saying that
they're not completely trustworthy, but

59
00:03:30.830 --> 00:03:34.230
you and I might not be able to name
a single person that works there, but

60
00:03:34.230 --> 00:03:37.900
yet I am now willing to
trust my own personal data

61
00:03:37.900 --> 00:03:40.680
to being stored out there because
I see the benefits of it.

62
00:03:40.680 --> 00:03:45.256
But what about real security on things
that really matter such as your business,

63
00:03:45.256 --> 00:03:47.949
stuff that you actually
have to keep private and

64
00:03:47.949 --> 00:03:52.622
secure due to compliance issues, due to
auditing issues, whatever it might be?

65
00:03:52.622 --> 00:03:57.747
You have to actually be able to keep the
security going the way that we need to.

66
00:03:57.747 --> 00:04:02.499
And so now all the sudden you realize that
the security measures that Daniel and

67
00:04:02.499 --> 00:04:07.251
I learned about when we first got started,
they apply to a point, but how do you

68
00:04:07.251 --> 00:04:12.030
actually take those measures and
apply them to something like Office 365?

69
00:04:12.030 --> 00:04:16.704
And that's what we're really focusing in
on right here today as we start thinking

70
00:04:16.704 --> 00:04:17.322
about it.

71
00:04:17.322 --> 00:04:22.298
So we do have to actually worry that there
is a chance that my data could get lost

72
00:04:22.298 --> 00:04:26.305
out there, could be compromised
by somebody else out there.

73
00:04:26.305 --> 00:04:28.340
I just don't know it.

74
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:31.520
So the good thing is in Office 365,

75
00:04:31.520 --> 00:04:36.230
there's a whole system out there
that they call rights management.

76
00:04:36.230 --> 00:04:39.040
So when we deal with the idea
of rights management,

77
00:04:39.040 --> 00:04:44.050
rights management is actually a layer
of security that we can implement,

78
00:04:44.050 --> 00:04:49.195
using Office 365,
to help us to protect the data itself.

79
00:04:49.195 --> 00:04:51.140
And this is true,

80
00:04:53.210 --> 00:04:57.476
when we use it with Office 365, whether
the data actually resides right here,

81
00:04:57.476 --> 00:05:03.680
whether it's actually in transmitting
from here up to Microsoft Office 365, or

82
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:08.100
whether I say Daniel, I'm gonna share this
file with you through OneDrive somewhere,

83
00:05:08.100 --> 00:05:11.060
and whether he actually
downloads it to his computer.

84
00:05:11.060 --> 00:05:15.140
We can actually manage those things
through what we call rights management.

85
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:16.840
Now this term is changed over the years,
and

86
00:05:16.840 --> 00:05:19.270
I want to point that out, because
those of you that are preparing for

87
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:22.910
the exam,
they have a test pool of exam questions.

88
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:26.890
And even though the terminology
has changed over time for

89
00:05:26.890 --> 00:05:30.850
this exam,
you might still find older terminology.

90
00:05:30.850 --> 00:05:37.730
So at one point you might've heard it
called Windows Azure Active Directory

91
00:05:37.730 --> 00:05:39.690
service or something like that.

92
00:05:39.690 --> 00:05:42.560
Today they just call it
Azure Active Directory and

93
00:05:42.560 --> 00:05:46.170
Azure Rights Management,
Windows Azure Rights Management.

94
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:47.970
When you hear all that,
it means the same thing.

95
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:51.008
You may even see the term thrown
in there that'll talk about

96
00:05:51.008 --> 00:05:55.225
Microsoft Azure Active Directory, and so
those two terms are kind of the new one.

97
00:05:55.225 --> 00:05:58.897
The one that's Azure Rights Management,
Microsoft Azure Rights Management,

98
00:05:58.897 --> 00:06:00.787
those are kinda the most recent ones, but

99
00:06:00.787 --> 00:06:04.980
I can't guarantee you on the exam that
you're gonna see those terms specifically.

100
00:06:04.980 --> 00:06:07.364
So just realize that if
you do see others terms,

101
00:06:07.364 --> 00:06:09.509
the key terms that you
want to focus in on and

102
00:06:09.509 --> 00:06:14.690
what we're really covering here today is
gonna be that idea of rights management.

103
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:16.896
>> Ronnie, really quickly,
when I think of rights management,

104
00:06:16.896 --> 00:06:18.976
and I wanna make sure I'm correct and
I'm following you and

105
00:06:18.976 --> 00:06:21.570
I wanna make sure everybody out
there is following you as well.

106
00:06:21.570 --> 00:06:25.050
When I think of rights management I'm
thinking, okay, I've got users and

107
00:06:25.050 --> 00:06:29.050
I'm giving them access to
something in the vein of if we had

108
00:06:30.340 --> 00:06:32.970
the permissions on like a file or
a folder.

109
00:06:32.970 --> 00:06:35.381
Is that what we're talking about here,
same kind of idea but

110
00:06:35.381 --> 00:06:36.385
just in a different way?

111
00:06:36.385 --> 00:06:39.769
>> Yeah, to a point,
it is about making sure that only

112
00:06:39.769 --> 00:06:44.257
the people that you give permissions
to are able to see the data, but

113
00:06:44.257 --> 00:06:48.460
at the same time it actually
goes beyond that idea.

114
00:06:48.460 --> 00:06:53.302
So that as long as it goes through
Office 6, Office 65 [LAUGH].

115
00:06:53.302 --> 00:06:54.908
I left off a 3 somewhere.

116
00:06:54.908 --> 00:06:57.203
>> Ronnie's got his own
product out there [LAUGH].

117
00:06:57.203 --> 00:07:01.757
>> Office 365, as long as essentially we
go through Office 365 with the rights

118
00:07:01.757 --> 00:07:03.605
management services turned on,

119
00:07:03.605 --> 00:07:07.103
it's really backed up by the entire
Azure Rights Management,

120
00:07:07.103 --> 00:07:12.370
which is a complete different product, but
Office 365 builds on top of that thing.

121
00:07:12.370 --> 00:07:16.620
As long as it goes through there,
we have the ability to control the data,

122
00:07:16.620 --> 00:07:19.570
regardless of where
the object is on this planet.

123
00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:23.070
So even if Daniel decided he was going
to take a vacation on the other side of

124
00:07:23.070 --> 00:07:26.006
the planet, and he said oh,
I need to get access to that file,

125
00:07:26.006 --> 00:07:29.694
even if he downloaded it onto his phone,
well, it would still be protected.

126
00:07:29.694 --> 00:07:34.810
So it actually does go a bit beyond
the idea of just simple permissions,

127
00:07:34.810 --> 00:07:36.460
and we need that.

128
00:07:36.460 --> 00:07:40.440
The reason why we need it is because
no longer are the devices in which we

129
00:07:40.440 --> 00:07:43.410
view our own company's data
just owned by the company.

130
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:45.840
In other words, they're not actually
just the ones that do that.

131
00:07:45.840 --> 00:07:49.484
I actually have my own phone which
I check my business email on.

132
00:07:49.484 --> 00:07:53.377
Not only that though, even things
that I might download files to,

133
00:07:53.377 --> 00:07:56.576
they're not necessarily
the company's machines but

134
00:07:56.576 --> 00:08:00.556
I do download my company files onto
my own personal machine as well.

135
00:08:00.556 --> 00:08:03.822
So we need the ability to have
protection in that way and

136
00:08:03.822 --> 00:08:08.516
this is regardless of whether or
not we're connected to Office 365 or not.

137
00:08:08.516 --> 00:08:12.045
Azure Rights Management absolutely
tries to protect the data.

138
00:08:12.045 --> 00:08:16.202
Now not only do we actually focus
in on just Office 365 data, but

139
00:08:16.202 --> 00:08:21.253
remember that because Office 365 is
a productivity suite that really extends

140
00:08:21.253 --> 00:08:26.630
into things like the storage that we were
talking about, and even in the email.

141
00:08:26.630 --> 00:08:29.270
It also extends all the way out there.

142
00:08:29.270 --> 00:08:34.238
As long as you actually start off with
Office 365 Rights Management turned on,

143
00:08:34.238 --> 00:08:38.207
you then can extend that integration
into your exchange server.

144
00:08:38.207 --> 00:08:41.221
You can extend it into
your SharePoint sites, and

145
00:08:41.221 --> 00:08:43.316
all of that stuff can be turned on.

146
00:08:43.316 --> 00:08:46.667
But the basics is what we're
talking about right here,

147
00:08:46.667 --> 00:08:51.515
where we actually show you where do we get
started and how do we begin to administer

148
00:08:51.515 --> 00:08:56.100
the Office 365 management services
is where we're actually starting.

149
00:08:56.100 --> 00:09:01.340
So it's a great thing for us to at least
have an understanding of, and it may come

150
00:09:01.340 --> 00:09:05.850
a point where you do, you actually have
to work this out with your organization.

151
00:09:06.950 --> 00:09:11.635
How is this gonna fit into your policy,
and where does all of this stuff turn on?

152
00:09:11.635 --> 00:09:15.450
And how do we actually get
the integration of our security policy

153
00:09:15.450 --> 00:09:19.540
with our on premise versus the way that we
also do it with Azure Rights Management.

154
00:09:19.540 --> 00:09:22.770
So there's a lot more to go
that's more technically detailed.

155
00:09:22.770 --> 00:09:26.264
But what we're actually doing here,
is we're gonna show you how to turn it on,

156
00:09:26.264 --> 00:09:29.759
and we also need to get into some of the
features that you can't actually just use

157
00:09:29.759 --> 00:09:31.300
the management portal to turn on.

158
00:09:31.300 --> 00:09:34.680
Some of them you can, but we're also
gonna go a little bit of PowerShell,

159
00:09:34.680 --> 00:09:36.790
to show you also how to
manage it there as well.

160
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:40.262
So there's a lot of different things and
PowerShell, of course,

161
00:09:40.262 --> 00:09:42.500
is Gates says it's the wave of the future.

162
00:09:42.500 --> 00:09:46.640
The very fact is, you're not gonna
be able to get around Microsoft

163
00:09:46.640 --> 00:09:50.840
services at all without at least knowing
a little bit of PowerShell to do so.

164
00:09:50.840 --> 00:09:53.350
As you get into exchange online and

165
00:09:53.350 --> 00:09:56.860
even the SharePoint stuff it's gonna
become more and more dependent on that,

166
00:09:56.860 --> 00:10:00.280
but we'll show you at least the basics
here today as we get started.

167
00:10:00.280 --> 00:10:01.900
So lets go ahead and jump in and

168
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:06.660
show you at least the beginnings
when we start to do this here, okay?

169
00:10:06.660 --> 00:10:11.730
So when we start doing this on my machine
here I'm running a Windows 10 machine,

170
00:10:11.730 --> 00:10:15.230
and there's a couple of different
things that we're gonna have to do.

171
00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:17.670
The first thing is as we get started

172
00:10:17.670 --> 00:10:20.200
there's gonna be two different
components to this, right?

173
00:10:20.200 --> 00:10:22.720
One is turning it on in the portal side,
and

174
00:10:22.720 --> 00:10:25.480
then secondly is how you
choose to manage it.

175
00:10:25.480 --> 00:10:28.860
So what we're also going to do is we're
gonna show you from the on premise

176
00:10:28.860 --> 00:10:32.920
site as well, using some of the PowerShell
stuff to get it ready and going.

177
00:10:32.920 --> 00:10:34.652
And so I'll show you the process and

178
00:10:34.652 --> 00:10:37.930
the steps that I use to make
sure that we turn this thing on.

179
00:10:37.930 --> 00:10:42.360
So the first thing I'm gonna do
is connect up to my Office 365.

180
00:10:42.360 --> 00:10:44.680
And let me see if I can
make that connection now.

181
00:10:46.640 --> 00:10:53.440
I'll use this browser right here,
portal@office.com, and in

182
00:10:53.440 --> 00:10:58.710
a moment I should get to my login portal
if everything is actually connected there.

183
00:10:58.710 --> 00:11:00.731
Oh, it's actually still

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue looking at Azure Rights Management to add security to our Office365 environments. They pick back up by explaining how to assign users or groups as role-based administrators for Azure RM. Finally they explain how even though there are role-based administrators, there will still be times when the Rights Management Super-User may need to be utilized. They walk you through assigning that job to a user.

can't actually look at the data.

340
00:18:37.490 --> 00:18:38.670
They're not going to be able to do so.

341
00:18:38.670 --> 00:18:43.470
So even though they can control
the overall process, and the overall

342
00:18:43.470 --> 00:18:47.810
structure, they don't have the ability to
go in and modify or change data, okay?

343
00:18:47.810 --> 00:18:52.270
The other thing that can also happen is
like with individual exchange mailboxes

344
00:18:52.270 --> 00:18:56.210
too, or stuff like that,
if it actually needs to be indexed.

345
00:18:56.210 --> 00:18:59.740
Well, even the rights
administrators can't actually index

346
00:18:59.740 --> 00:19:02.200
a ready encrypted types of mailboxes.

347
00:19:02.200 --> 00:19:05.280
But, with a super user account,
they can as well.

348
00:19:05.280 --> 00:19:08.400
So that's what needs to also happen too,
is that someone inside of

349
00:19:08.400 --> 00:19:12.320
your organization is probably gonna
end up getting accesses role.

350
00:19:12.320 --> 00:19:13.045
And more than likely,

351
00:19:13.045 --> 00:19:15.610
it's gonna be the global administrator
who ends up getting access.

352
00:19:15.610 --> 00:19:18.600
But it can be delegated out and
that's pretty much the key.

353
00:19:18.600 --> 00:19:22.330
>> Well, Ronnie, now that we have
the role-based administrator set or

354
00:19:22.330 --> 00:19:25.690
a group of role-based administrator
set up, we're good to go, right?

355
00:19:25.690 --> 00:19:28.630
We've got the all knowing,
all seeing, dictators of our system.

356
00:19:28.630 --> 00:19:30.010
We're able to assign rights and

357
00:19:30.010 --> 00:19:32.472
do anything that we want to
do with those people, right?

358
00:19:32.472 --> 00:19:36.620
>> Just about, right,
that is not exactly everything, okay?

359
00:19:36.620 --> 00:19:39.430
With the rights management guys, right?

360
00:19:39.430 --> 00:19:42.220
They do have complete
control over that ability

361
00:19:42.220 --> 00:19:44.780
to do some of the things
that they really need to do.

362
00:19:44.780 --> 00:19:47.290
But there comes an issue and
there comes a point, right?

363
00:19:47.290 --> 00:19:54.340
So they are kind of sovereign over
the very fact that they can administrate.

364
00:19:54.340 --> 00:19:57.390
The fact that we're using
rights management and

365
00:19:57.390 --> 00:19:59.330
we're not actually doing anything else.

366
00:19:59.330 --> 00:20:01.300
We can hand over that control.

367
00:20:01.300 --> 00:20:05.530
But there are still a few things that
the rights administrators cannot do,

368
00:20:05.530 --> 00:20:08.050
the rights management admins cannot do.

369
00:20:08.050 --> 00:20:11.770
And that is to actually be
able to essentially look

370
00:20:11.770 --> 00:20:14.780
at the user's data that we're protecting.

371
00:20:14.780 --> 00:20:18.457
And that is very important
because there are scenarios,

372
00:20:18.457 --> 00:20:22.211
there are things that end up
happening to organizations,

373
00:20:22.211 --> 00:20:26.380
in which we still need to able
to prevent the loss of data.

374
00:20:26.380 --> 00:20:31.670
And even though rights management
helps us to prevent some loss of data,

375
00:20:31.670 --> 00:20:35.930
there are some things it cannot do unless
we give them the permission to do so.

376
00:20:35.930 --> 00:20:40.470
So there is another level of
this idea of the rights admin

377
00:20:40.470 --> 00:20:44.120
that we call the super user feature,
that we also need to enable.

378
00:20:44.120 --> 00:20:46.840
Now, you might be wondering about
some of those scenarios, right?

379
00:20:46.840 --> 00:20:49.910
So let me kind of give you
an example of a couple of scenarios.

380
00:20:51.240 --> 00:20:54.380
An organization that has
employees that end up leaving, and

381
00:20:54.380 --> 00:20:57.990
they have sensitive data that
we still need to recover.

382
00:20:57.990 --> 00:21:01.370
Well, the admin rights,
or the rights admin,

383
00:21:01.370 --> 00:21:03.290
why am I not gonna be able to say that.

384
00:21:03.290 --> 00:21:09.560
The rights management, the admins, they
can't touch that data, it's encrypted.

385
00:21:09.560 --> 00:21:11.700
And they're not actually
allowed to view that data,

386
00:21:11.700 --> 00:21:13.630
but it still needs to be recovered.

387
00:21:13.630 --> 00:21:17.170
Well, you might think, well, they're
in charge of the data loss prevention

388
00:21:17.170 --> 00:21:18.860
by using this rights management.

389
00:21:18.860 --> 00:21:20.952
But yeah, they're not able to
go to an individual user and

390
00:21:20.952 --> 00:21:23.014
actually pull that data,
that's absolutely correct.

391
00:21:23.014 --> 00:21:25.097
They're not able to do
something like that.

392
00:21:25.097 --> 00:21:30.710
The other thing is also is the ability
to remove current protection.

393
00:21:30.710 --> 00:21:35.200
And also to be able to configure and apply
different policies that are there for

394
00:21:35.200 --> 00:21:36.700
individual users too.

395
00:21:36.700 --> 00:21:39.280
So, even though they have the ability
to say, all right, we're using this and

396
00:21:39.280 --> 00:21:42.580
how we can control some of it,
for users they can't do that.

397
00:21:42.580 --> 00:21:46.683
Even for exchange mailboxes, as well,
to index to protected mailboxes,

398
00:21:46.683 --> 00:21:49.431
they're not actually
allowed to do that either.

399
00:21:49.431 --> 00:21:53.439
So, there's a couple of different
scenarios out there that you do have to

400
00:21:53.439 --> 00:21:54.223
worry about.

401
00:21:54.223 --> 00:21:56.043
And so, what has to happen then,

402
00:21:56.043 --> 00:22:00.530
is that even though we can actually assign
individual users as being the admins for

403
00:22:00.530 --> 00:22:04.432
rights management, or groups as
being admins for rights management,

404
00:22:04.432 --> 00:22:08.510
we talk about the idea of bringing
in the super user feature.

405
00:22:08.510 --> 00:22:11.431
This is the one, and this is where
I got it completely wrong before.

406
00:22:11.431 --> 00:22:16.048
This is the one that can only be
done with an individual account, and

407
00:22:16.048 --> 00:22:19.410
not a complete group of accounts instead.

408
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:24.285
So, we only assign them to really a few
people instead when we start doing this.

409
00:22:24.285 --> 00:22:27.030
Now, if you don't have this, right?

410
00:22:27.030 --> 00:22:30.230
There is a possibility you
are gonna still lose data.

411
00:22:30.230 --> 00:22:34.510
So not only do you need the admins for
rights management to be there,

412
00:22:34.510 --> 00:22:37.590
in terms of that role based feature
that Daniel was talking about, but

413
00:22:37.590 --> 00:22:41.880
we're also gonna probably need at least
one, that's gonna be this super user,

414
00:22:41.880 --> 00:22:45.520
that's gonna have the super
user feature enabled for them.

415
00:22:45.520 --> 00:22:47.886
If we need to do some of the scenarios
that we talked about, and

416
00:22:47.886 --> 00:22:50.940
there's a few more out there that
you can look up and see too.

417
00:22:50.940 --> 00:22:54.090
So, it has to be a combination
of these things.

418
00:22:54.090 --> 00:22:58.811
The key here is just trying to remember,
you know, when do I use that or,

419
00:22:58.811 --> 00:23:02.640
you know, in what situation,
especially us preparing for the exam,

420
00:23:02.640 --> 00:23:07.930
that I would need that idea of that super
user account to be able to do this.

421
00:23:07.930 --> 00:23:10.680
And so, when you actually think
about that, then you know,

422
00:23:10.680 --> 00:23:14.070
is it gonna be the rights, you know,
the normal administrator for

423
00:23:14.070 --> 00:23:15.890
rights management that has to do this?

424
00:23:15.890 --> 00:23:19.350
Or is it somebody that actually has
to have that super user feature too?

425
00:23:19.350 --> 00:23:25.310
Now just like the way that we talked
about enabling rights management, right?

426
00:23:25.310 --> 00:23:30.230
Well, we also can enable
this super user feature too.

427
00:23:30.230 --> 00:23:32.055
And make sure that it works, as well.

428
00:23:32.055 --> 00:23:36.645
Now this is also a two-step process for
us, so something that we really

429
00:23:36.645 --> 00:23:41.638
want to make sure that we pay attention
to as we bring this up here, all right?

430
00:23:41.638 --> 00:23:44.130
So, let's go ahead and do this.

431
00:23:44.130 --> 00:23:47.650
Now, I'm actually using this
Azure Active Directory Module for

432
00:23:47.650 --> 00:23:50.240
Windows PowerShell here to help us out.

433
00:23:50.240 --> 00:23:54.046
So from the PowerShell command,
let me go ahead and

434
00:23:54.046 --> 00:23:56.886
connect back in to the AADRM service.

435
00:23:56.886 --> 00:24:00.967
And even though I know that I'm
actually connected right now,

436
00:24:00.967 --> 00:24:06.130
this is something, again, that may Be
something that you actually want to do.

437
00:24:06.130 --> 00:24:11.177
So it's just, at least for
me, a safety check demo.

438
00:24:12.863 --> 00:24:14.571
Come on.

439
00:24:16.988 --> 00:24:18.857
Be sure I paste that password in.

440
00:24:18.857 --> 00:24:21.375
And it's always nice to verify
that you are connected and

441
00:24:21.375 --> 00:24:22.696
then that your ready to work.

442
00:24:22.696 --> 00:24:25.695
Or, this may not be something that
you do right after a string of other

443
00:24:25.695 --> 00:24:26.480
things, right?

444
00:24:26.480 --> 00:24:30.120
So, making sure that it's actually up and
ready is what you wanna do.

445
00:24:30.120 --> 00:24:35.316
To enable the feature,
it's simply Enable-,

446
00:24:35.316 --> 00:24:42.830
and it's right here that we do aadrm,
and then SuperUserFeature.

447
00:24:42.830 --> 00:24:46.770
And it's simple enough to actually
be able to remember, okay.

448
00:24:46.770 --> 00:24:51.966
So if I go ahead and press Enter there,
that should now enable that feature.

449
00:24:51.966 --> 00:24:55.580
And now you should get a confirmation,
The super user feature is enabled for

450
00:24:55.580 --> 00:24:57.003
Rights Management service.

451
00:24:57.003 --> 00:25:00.940
But you're not done, okay, so
just like we talked with activation,

452
00:25:00.940 --> 00:25:06.100
and then making sure that we turn that
service on, or enable that service.

453
00:25:06.100 --> 00:25:08.000
Here we enabled the service so

454
00:25:08.000 --> 00:25:11.170
that we know that the super
user feature can be enabled.

455
00:25:11.170 --> 00:25:15.260
But it doesn't work until you actually
assign a administrator to it, okay.

456
00:25:15.260 --> 00:25:17.917
So that is the actual key for
us next here.

457
00:25:17.917 --> 00:25:22.851
So, again, fairly easy,

458
00:25:22.851 --> 00:25:27.790
we Add-AadrmSuperUser.

459
00:25:27.790 --> 00:25:30.550
And from this point,
you have a couple of options.

460
00:25:30.550 --> 00:25:33.910
If I leave it like this,
it'll still work, let me go and show you.

461
00:25:33.910 --> 00:25:36.710
So I'm just gonna leave
it as Add SuperUser.

462
00:25:36.710 --> 00:25:38.640
And then it's asking me for
an email address.

463
00:25:38.640 --> 00:25:41.405
I could've also simply typed in a dash, or

464
00:25:41.405 --> 00:25:45.520
used the option EmailAddress at
the end and typed in who I wanted to.

465
00:25:45.520 --> 00:25:54.490
And this one I'm gonna
mike@itprotvdemo.com, and press Enter.

466
00:25:55.910 --> 00:25:59.158
And here it should actually go out and
find the account, and there it is.

467
00:25:59.158 --> 00:26:02.370
So now he is also added to
the list of super users,

468
00:26:02.370 --> 00:26:07.650
and now we have our super user
administrator for us and ready to go.

469
00:26:07.650 --> 00:26:09.380
So remember that with the super user,

470
00:26:09.380 --> 00:26:14.293
right, he can access protected data,
even when the user leaves the company.

471
00:26:14.293 --> 00:26:17.680
Okay, so that's actually a big help
that we can actually think about.

472
00:26:17.680 --> 00:26:21.330
He can change any of the policies
that are already in place for

473
00:26:21.330 --> 00:26:23.555
us, even after they've been applied.

474
00:26:23.555 --> 00:26:26.330
So that's something that is kind of neat.

475
00:26:26.330 --> 00:26:30.460
That, essentially, if a policy is applied
to Daniel's account, he can actually go in

00:26:30.460 --> 00:26:34.025
and change those Rights Management
features for Daniel if he needs to.

477
00:26:34.025 --> 00:26:37.010
Index the protected email boxes as well.

478
00:26:37.010 --> 00:26:40.610
Be able to perform things like
bulk decryption when we need to.

479
00:26:40.610 --> 00:26:43.940
You name it, there's a lot of
things that can actually be done.

480
00:26:43.940 --> 00:26:47.160
Now, we just showed you how
to manually enable it and

481
00:26:47.160 --> 00:26:49.320
set who the administrator is.

482
00:26:49.320 --> 00:26:51.340
If you decide that you're
gonna actually extend, and

483
00:26:51.340 --> 00:26:53.060
this is probably what you'll end up doing.

484
00:26:53.060 --> 00:26:55.945
Is not only Rights Management for
Office 365, but

485
00:26:55.945 --> 00:26:59.547
you choose to extend it out to,
of course, your Exchange Server.

486
00:26:59.547 --> 00:27:04.454
By default, once you choose to extend that
out, whoever's actually logged in doing

487
00:27:04.454 --> 00:27:09.470
it with their credentials, that person
will become the super user anyways.

488
00:27:09.470 --> 00:27:11.790
So, you have two options there, right.

489
00:27:11.790 --> 00:27:14.380
If you need a super user account,
you can either go ahead and

490
00:27:14.380 --> 00:27:17.720
do the Integrated Rights Management for
Exchange Online,

491
00:27:17.720 --> 00:27:19.740
and that will automatically
added in there.

492
00:27:19.740 --> 00:27:22.420
Or manually,
you do it the way that we showed you, and

493
00:27:22.420 --> 00:27:24.543
that will allow you to have
that feature available.

494
00:27:24.543 --> 00:27:30.040
So, even though the role-based types of
Rights Management admins that we've talked

495
00:27:30.040 --> 00:27:34.560
about is exactly what we need to make sure
that we have somebody in control of it.

496
00:27:34.560 --> 00:27:37.680
To be able to have full and
active control as well,

497
00:27:37.680 --> 00:27:41.130
we need to make sure that we also have

498
00:27:41.130 --> 00:27:44.522
That will really help us to
recover data that is lost and

499
00:27:44.522 --> 00:27:48.375
do some of the things that the even
the right admins can't do.

500
00:27:48.375 --> 00:27:50.281
>> Awesome, now is that going to be, well,

00:27:50.281 --> 00:27:52.520
within the scope of what
we're doing right now?

00:27:52.520 --> 00:27:54.990
Are we gonna get into that

503
00:27:54.990 --> 00:27:57.650
>> Yeah, we're gonna get into

504
00:27:57.650 --> 00:28:02.460
So, we're not doing too much more than
just making sure that we understand

00:28:02.460 --> 00:28:06.070
what the role of that super user is, and
what the role of the Rights Management is.

506
00:28:06.070 --> 00:28:09.290
And remember that we don't have a portal

00:28:09.290 --> 00:28:12.230

that stuff up as well.

And that's why we have to do

509
00:28:14.380 --> 00:28:18.697
So knowing those commands, understanding
the concepts that we talked about here,

510
00:28:18.697 --> 00:28:22.243
are gonna help you way on your way
towards getting ready for the exam.

511
00:28:22.243 --> 00:28:25.407
As well as, as you start setting
this up for your roll out or

512
00:28:25.407 --> 00:28:27.292
your migration to Office 365.

513
00:28:27.292 --> 00:28:30.747
>> So, memorize for your exam,
and then create a cheat sheet for

00:28:30.747 --> 00:28:32.817
in real life, that's how it works.

00:28:32.817 --> 00:28:34.098
Or Google it, obviously, right?

516
00:28:34.098 --> 00:28:35.003
>> [LAUGH] Yeah that's-
>> And

00:28:35.003 --> 00:28:37.736
welcome to real IT systems administration.

518
00:28:37.736 --> 00:28:39.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> Google is your friend.

519
00:28:39.880 --> 00:28:42.830
Ronnie, is there anything else we need to
cover before we close this episode down?

00:28:42.830 --> 00:28:46.365
>> Not really for anything dealing with
the idea of this Rights Management, right?

521
00:28:46.365 --> 00:28:49.880
>> There is a lot more than

But just getting it enabled is one of

523
00:28:53.530 --> 00:28:57.300
Most of the other things dealing with
the SharePoint and the Exchange,

it will become more customized depending

00:29:01.300 --> 00:29:04.350
So you do have to actually

526
00:29:04.350 --> 00:29:08.430
But overall though, here's the basics
that will at least get you started and

527
00:29:08.430 --> 00:29:12.960
get your understanding what things must be

528
00:29:12.960 --> 00:29:15.522
>> Awesome, well thank you so
much for joining us today and

00:29:15.522 --> 00:29:17.975
showing us how to enable this,
get this thing going so

00:29:17.975 --> 00:29:21.570

531
00:29:21.570 --> 00:29:23.877
Thank you guys for watching,
we enjoy having you everyday,

00:29:23.877 --> 00:29:25.244

00:29:25.244 --> 00:29:29.325
But we are ready to sign off for ITProTV,

00:29:29.325 --> 00:29:30.065

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel take a look at managing the different administrator roles in Office365. They begin by explaining that Office365 uses role based permissions and that is done through role-based administrators. They describe the 8 Administrator roles, Global, Billing, Password, Service, User Management, Exchange Online, Sharepoint Online, and Skype for Business Online admins. Finally they show you how to enable these roles for the necessary user(s), using both the Portal and PowerShell.
episodes.title: Office365 Admin Roles

topics.title: Plan and implement networking and security in Office 365

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explore user and password management in Office365. They cover topics like how to set a password expiration time as well as setting whether or not to enable password complexity rules. Finally they show you how to use the password reset center.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue explaining user and password management in Office365. They start by looking at user administration, specifically bulk user creation utilizing a Comma-Separated Value(CSV) file and then move to deleted account recovery. Finally they demonstrate multi-factor authentication.

UserPrincipalName and

More and more as we actually

Now when we working with this

It depends on how much you

If you just have Office 365,

00:31:55.721 --> 00:31:59.664
in other words, the infrastructure set

Of just the most basic of

So I'm simply going to close out of my

So this actually does give now

Now you'll see that I've already set one

So by doing this, it really does help

Remember that even though they

It meets all the complexity requirements,

it's a combination of four letters and

That still is a relatively complex, but

By using the multi factor authentication,

Normally this is going to be a device

So by being able to actually

We showed you where you

And we're actually going to have

00:35:21.680 --> 00:35:25.270
But then, the last thing here,

Something that we all need to

You can't trust a lot more people, and

Multi-factor authentication is

us that we should all get used to using.

Yes, it's definitely a lot

00:35:47.150 --> 00:35:48.920

When it comes to managing users or

00:35:51.760 --> 00:35:55.650

But the good thing is that

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explore managing cloud identities with PowerShell. Here they will show you how to configure non-expiring passwords, bulk user creation and updating user properties. They also cover bulk user license management and hard-deleting user accounts.
episodes.title: Manage Cloud Identities

365 identities and requirements, you know

And we know that we can actually go

And so that means a lot of times,

00:01:10.840 --> 00:01:14.902
what we wanna do instead is work inside

00:01:14.902 --> 00:01:18.920

That sometimes they don't wanna make it

So they do give us that 30 day grace

00:02:08.880 --> 00:02:12.990
An Active Directory Recycle Bin inside of

39
00:02:16.030 --> 00:02:20.060
So this means that somebody can't

>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

>> And we'll see you next time.

710
00:41:50.827 --> 00:41:56.530

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel discuss what preparations need to be made for connecting and synching your on-premise Active Directory environment to your Office365 cloud service. They begin by explaining reasons you would want to synchronize and then move into planing for non-routable domains. Next, they talk about some items that need to be cleaned up because they might hinder the Office365 deployment and employ some tools like IdFix and ADModify.NET to help with this process.
episodes.title: Sync to Office365

But the very fact is at

in this particular little subdomain that

When I have this, there is no
