change that if we wanted to.

687
00:35:29.040 --> 00:35:33.200
So here's another way that we can go ahead
and modify every single one of those

688
00:35:33.200 --> 00:35:35.900
instead of having to go through and
search the Active Directory,

689
00:35:35.900 --> 00:35:39.240
it essentially allows me to pick it up and
then I can go back and run through and

690
00:35:39.240 --> 00:35:43.710
pick the next one, next one, next one and
modify what I need to individually there.

691
00:35:43.710 --> 00:35:45.460
So, depending on what your action is.

692
00:35:45.460 --> 00:35:48.450
If it's a small number,
that may be the way to go.

693
00:35:48.450 --> 00:35:49.270
Large numbers, though,

694
00:35:49.270 --> 00:35:52.620
you might be wondering what am
I gonna do with a large number?

695
00:35:52.620 --> 00:35:56.030
Well, if you did have multiple
objects that have the same errors,

696
00:35:56.030 --> 00:35:57.350
this is where PowerShell comes in.

697
00:35:57.350 --> 00:36:02.140
Being able to modify attributes in bulk is
some of the things that we've also done in

698
00:36:02.140 --> 00:36:05.260
a previous episode, so
make sure you check how to do that.

699
00:36:05.260 --> 00:36:07.830
You can do it right here against
your active directory domain.

700
00:36:07.830 --> 00:36:11.700
Or you can do it against the Active
Directory up in Office 365 as well and

701
00:36:11.700 --> 00:36:16.300
we did do a little show on
that where we took PowerShell,

702
00:36:16.300 --> 00:36:19.880
showed you how to modify
attributes inside of Office 365.

703
00:36:19.880 --> 00:36:23.140
So you just change domain and
you are ready to go.

704
00:36:23.140 --> 00:36:26.790
So, being able to do stuff like that is
really some of the preparation work that

705
00:36:26.790 --> 00:36:27.900
needs to be done.

706
00:36:27.900 --> 00:36:30.220
So remember that we needn't
have that decision, right?

707
00:36:30.220 --> 00:36:32.330
What is the ultimate
result that I need to see.

708
00:36:32.330 --> 00:36:35.840
And then to get my active
directory prepared

709
00:36:35.840 --> 00:36:40.530
I may need to verify that my DNS name
is actually something that's routable.

710
00:36:40.530 --> 00:36:43.910
If it's not, know how to actually
get around that routability

711
00:36:43.910 --> 00:36:45.690
by using the UPN suffix.

712
00:36:45.690 --> 00:36:48.500
And then take a look at
your active directory and

713
00:36:48.500 --> 00:36:51.580
running through some of those
utilities and tools to prepare it.

714
00:36:51.580 --> 00:36:53.840
Getting ready for
that active directory sync.

715
00:36:53.840 --> 00:36:56.890
>> Awesome stuff Rowney very
excellent tools available to us

716
00:36:56.890 --> 00:36:59.150
to help make this run
a little more smoothly.

717
00:36:59.150 --> 00:37:01.480
Now that being said, I know Rowney,

718
00:37:01.480 --> 00:37:04.981
you've got a whole lot more to talk about
actually we are not even close to done.

719
00:37:04.981 --> 00:37:06.647
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're gonna have to move it

720
00:37:06.647 --> 00:37:09.865
to part two cuz looking at the clock,
that joker has long since expired.

721
00:37:09.865 --> 00:37:10.380
>> [LAUGHS]
>> So

722
00:37:10.380 --> 00:37:11.820
Ronnie I look forward to seeing you there.

723
00:37:11.820 --> 00:37:13.490
We hope to see you there as well.

724
00:37:13.490 --> 00:37:15.750
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

725
00:37:15.750 --> 00:37:17.380
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

726
00:37:17.380 --> 00:37:18.110
>> And I'm Ronnie Long.

727
00:37:18.110 --> 00:37:19.471
>> And we'll see you next time.

728
00:37:19.471 --> 00:37:25.420
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue preparing for synching on-premise Active Directory servers with Office365. They pick up by explaining filtering of the Active Directory domain, Organizational Units(OUs), and Object Attributes.
episodes.title: Sync to Office 365 Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.836 --> 00:00:16.421
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.421 --> 00:00:20.610
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode well we are continuing on

4
00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:25.040
with our Office 365 identities and
requirements, specifically a part

5
00:00:25.040 --> 00:00:28.700
two here on synchronizing
Active Directory with Office 365.

6
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:34.070
And joining us yet again, welcoming him
back, is our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:34.960
Ronnie welcome back to the show.

8
00:00:34.960 --> 00:00:35.750
How are you doing?

9
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:38.500
>> I'm doing great as we continue
on to take a look at Office 365,

10
00:00:38.500 --> 00:00:41.780
especially Active Directory
synchronization, right?

11
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:45.240
The ability to insure that our on premises
Active Directory is also gonna sync up

12
00:00:45.240 --> 00:00:48.350
with what we normally have in
the background of Office 365.

13
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:52.420
Which is gonna be
the Azure Active Directory that's

14
00:00:52.420 --> 00:00:55.890
back there holding up that
end of the deal for us.

15
00:00:55.890 --> 00:01:00.170
And what we also need to be able to do
of course, is realize something that,

16
00:01:00.170 --> 00:01:03.140
if we're gonna be having where
everything is gonna come together and

17
00:01:03.140 --> 00:01:04.800
it needs to work together.

18
00:01:04.800 --> 00:01:08.530
We also need to realize that not
everything that we have on our on-premises

19
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:13.130
needs to be synced up to
the Azure Active Directory, as well.

20
00:01:13.130 --> 00:01:15.770
Normally, when we do something like this,
it's fairly easy to just say, all right,

21
00:01:15.770 --> 00:01:19.230
let's just do this all blanket, and
we turn over everything over there.

22
00:01:19.230 --> 00:01:22.190
But, remember, that there's always gonna
be some things that you'll have inside

23
00:01:22.190 --> 00:01:25.650
your own network that doesn't
actually need to be synced.

24
00:01:25.650 --> 00:01:29.060
And the more stuff that you send over,
eats up bandwidth, of course,

25
00:01:29.060 --> 00:01:32.380
between your connection and
of course Office 365.

26
00:01:32.380 --> 00:01:35.540
And that means users will end up
slowing down as you have more and

27
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:36.940
more objects to sync.

28
00:01:36.940 --> 00:01:38.870
So the better idea of course then,

29
00:01:38.870 --> 00:01:43.170
is to make sure you know how to
set up everything so that you go.

30
00:01:43.170 --> 00:01:48.420
Hey, look, here are the absolute things
that need to be synchronized up there.

31
00:01:48.420 --> 00:01:50.920
But everything else I just
wanna leave on mine and

32
00:01:50.920 --> 00:01:54.410
not have it sync across
the network connection.

33
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:57.140
And that's what we also need to plan for,
too.

34
00:01:57.140 --> 00:02:00.420
So when you are actually thinking
about this synchronization, you do.

35
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:04.400
You need to take into consideration those
things that need to be synced up, and

36
00:02:04.400 --> 00:02:07.110
those things that do not
need to be synced up.

37
00:02:07.110 --> 00:02:10.280
And ensure that your Active Directory
is set up in that way that actually

38
00:02:10.280 --> 00:02:11.450
makes it easy.

39
00:02:11.450 --> 00:02:15.170
Now, when we start talking then about
how do we actually figure this out and

40
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:17.440
what do we do if we want that to happen.

41
00:02:17.440 --> 00:02:20.450
Is you and I have to be able to set
up what we call of course then,

42
00:02:20.450 --> 00:02:22.630
Active Directory filtering,

43
00:02:22.630 --> 00:02:26.290
that will allow us to filter that out
before we do the synchronization.

44
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:29.570
The way that the synchronization happens
is that just about every three hours it's

45
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:32.680
going to try and do some sync, and
normally what we're syncing up, of course,

46
00:02:32.680 --> 00:02:33.610
are changes.

47
00:02:33.610 --> 00:02:37.570
But that initial synchronization if you
take every object in Active Directory,

48
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:40.730
it can take a long time in
doing the synchronization.

49
00:02:40.730 --> 00:02:44.010
So before you start that,
you want to go ahead and plan out, hey,

50
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:47.580
here's what I want to sync up and
here's what I do not want to sync up.

51
00:02:47.580 --> 00:02:52.450
And so the way that they break this down
for us in terms of best practices for

52
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:57.440
Office 365, is to think about it
in three different ways, okay?

53
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:01.840
What domains do I want to sync up, or
single domain do I want to sync up?

54
00:03:01.840 --> 00:03:05.210
And that means if I'm in
an Active Directory environment,

55
00:03:05.210 --> 00:03:06.780
in which there are multiple domains.

56
00:03:06.780 --> 00:03:09.410
For example,
I showed you in another episode,

57
00:03:09.410 --> 00:03:13.190
that I have not only ITProTVdemo.com,

58
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:16.510
which is the one that we're using
as our main demonstration here.

59
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:19.670
But I also have my own lab environment,
and my own lab environment

60
00:03:19.670 --> 00:03:23.160
is not necessarily the one that I
need to sync up, but it may be.

61
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:26.870
And I need to consider if I'm gonna
do that to maybe limit it to that.

62
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:28.840
But what about multiple
other ones out there?

63
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:30.870
But I really don't need to sync those up.

64
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:34.700
I don't wanna take an entire Active
Directory forest with multiple domains and

65
00:03:34.700 --> 00:03:39.420
sync up everything, if I really only need
to sync up one or two possible domains.

66
00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:42.420
Cuz remember, we're actually
talking about generating traffic.

67
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:43.680
People are connecting to Office 365,

68
00:03:43.680 --> 00:03:47.320
and you're still generating traffic there,
it's gonna cause a lot of bottlenecks if

69
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:49.180
you have a fairly limited
amount of bandwidth.

70
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:50.010
>> So Ronnie, what do we do?

71
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:51.510
We've got all this information.

72
00:03:51.510 --> 00:03:53.546
We know that some of it's not going to,

73
00:03:53.546 --> 00:03:56.830
or at least it doesn't need to
be synced over to Office 365.

74
00:03:56.830 --> 00:04:00.120
How do we differentiate and
let Office know,

75
00:04:00.120 --> 00:04:05.210
hey this is the only stuff you actually
need to be aware of and filter that down?

76
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:08.520
>> Yeah the good thing is, you don't
have to do it in the manual process

77
00:04:08.520 --> 00:04:10.990
in terms of you trying to
figure out through PowerShell.

78
00:04:10.990 --> 00:04:12.250
Now can you if you want to?

79
00:04:12.250 --> 00:04:12.820
Yes.

80
00:04:12.820 --> 00:04:17.140
[LAUGH] If you absolutely wanna learn how
to do that, there are ways of course,

81
00:04:17.140 --> 00:04:20.110
that you can script that out to
pull out exactly what you need.

82
00:04:20.110 --> 00:04:22.800
But the nice thing is,
the way that Active Directory

83
00:04:22.800 --> 00:04:26.860
begins to do the synchronization for
us, is that it gives us a tool that

84
00:04:26.860 --> 00:04:30.800
we can actually use in the overall
process of synchronizing everything.

85
00:04:30.800 --> 00:04:35.420
But before we do so, that tool also of
course once you install that, allows

86
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:39.880
you to have access to what some other
tools that installs in the background too.

87
00:04:39.880 --> 00:04:41.476
So even though we haven't
gotten to the point,

88
00:04:41.476 --> 00:04:43.960
where weâ€™re actually doing
the synchronization.

89
00:04:43.960 --> 00:04:49.620
There are tools that we need to install
from that particular synchronization tool,

90
00:04:49.620 --> 00:04:53.530
and then we can use those tools to help
us, before we actually sync up anything.

91
00:04:53.530 --> 00:04:54.900
So I know it sounds strange.

92
00:04:54.900 --> 00:04:57.650
We download and install this
synchronization tool, we just don't run

93
00:04:57.650 --> 00:05:01.600
this synchronization yet, and then we use
the other tools that come along with it.

94
00:05:01.600 --> 00:05:03.360
Actually do some of the things
we're talking about, and

95
00:05:03.360 --> 00:05:05.950
specifically we're talking about
the idea of filtering here is what we

96
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:07.330
are taking a look at.

97
00:05:07.330 --> 00:05:11.180
So let me show you what I'm talking
about when we get started here.

98
00:05:11.180 --> 00:05:16.320
So the tool that we normally end up using,
is one that has actually changed names

99
00:05:16.320 --> 00:05:21.430
over a period of years, so the initial
one was the one that was called DirSync.

100
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:23.045
I know it sounds weird, but

101
00:05:23.045 --> 00:05:28.930
D-I-R-S-Y-N-C DirSync is the tool
that I remember getting started with.

102
00:05:28.930 --> 00:05:32.940
And then over the years, it changed
into Windows Active Directory Sync, and

103
00:05:32.940 --> 00:05:36.870
then there was just Active Directory
Synchronization Online, and

104
00:05:36.870 --> 00:05:38.270
there were a couple of other ones.

105
00:05:38.270 --> 00:05:41.480
But today, the most current
version is the one that they call

106
00:05:41.480 --> 00:05:44.430
Azure Active Directory Connect.

107
00:05:44.430 --> 00:05:46.360
So let me show you here.

108
00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:48.440
So here in
the Azure Active Directory Connect,

109
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:51.050
we're gonna be installing
this tool later on.

110
00:05:51.050 --> 00:05:54.320
But just kind of realize, I've already
installed it so that we could at least get

111
00:05:54.320 --> 00:05:58.430
used to seeing the tool for
the filtering that we need to.

112
00:05:58.430 --> 00:06:01.830
Once we install the tools,
it's gonna ask us a lot of questions, and

113
00:06:01.830 --> 00:06:04.100
it's gonna install
essentially an appliance,

114
00:06:04.100 --> 00:06:08.730
a server in the background that once we
install it, it's set and you forget it.

115
00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:14.280
But along with that utility comes,
well a bunch of other utilities here.

116
00:06:14.280 --> 00:06:17.380
And let me see if I can scroll
on over just a little bit here.

117
00:06:17.380 --> 00:06:19.990
So notice underneath Azure AD Connect.

118
00:06:19.990 --> 00:06:22.010
There's Azure AD Connect.

119
00:06:22.010 --> 00:06:24.120
There's Synchronization Rules Editor.

120
00:06:24.120 --> 00:06:26.320
And we're gonna get into
that a little bit later on.

121
00:06:26.320 --> 00:06:29.270
There's also the Synchronization Server,
and

122
00:06:29.270 --> 00:06:32.130
the Synchronization
Service Key Management.

123
00:06:32.130 --> 00:06:34.750
All these are actually managers,
is what they are.

124
00:06:34.750 --> 00:06:36.930
And the one that we're looking for
to help us to filter out,

125
00:06:36.930 --> 00:06:39.400
is gonna be the Synchronization Service.

126
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:42.650
So I'm just going to click on that,
and that will bring up this Azure

127
00:06:42.650 --> 00:06:48.460
synchronization service manager on my
machine is what we want to be able to do.

128
00:06:48.460 --> 00:06:49.070
Okay.

129
00:06:49.070 --> 00:06:54.710
Now this tool in itself, right,
doesn't run very easily if you just go.

130
00:06:54.710 --> 00:06:58.760
Oh its just single too, but it's because
of the way that its installed and

131
00:06:58.760 --> 00:07:01.210
it gather up some information
in the background,

132
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:03.000
that also really helps us out here.

133
00:07:03.000 --> 00:07:03.770
Okay.

134
00:07:03.770 --> 00:07:06.070
So once we get in here, okay, and

135
00:07:06.070 --> 00:07:10.680
we wanna talk about the idea of syncing
up or filtering out just by domain.

136
00:07:10.680 --> 00:07:14.989
Cuz that's one of the major features
that we can do is I click on connectors.

137
00:07:16.750 --> 00:07:21.000
And once I click on connectors,
you can see right here what it's done.

138
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:22.440
There it is.

139
00:07:22.440 --> 00:07:26.160
Here is my Azure Active Directory,
so I can connect to this domain and

140
00:07:26.160 --> 00:07:31.750
the synchronization, or I can also
connect here which is the on premises.

141
00:07:31.750 --> 00:07:34.810
So notice that this synchronization
service manager sees both.

142
00:07:34.810 --> 00:07:36.930
Now, we haven't run any
synchronization here.

143
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:39.596
I ensured that I didn't do that, but

144
00:07:39.596 --> 00:07:45.358
if I wanted to ensure that I was only this
one domain or to choose another domain,

145
00:07:45.358 --> 00:07:49.585
I can right click on that domain and
go down to properties.

146
00:07:49.585 --> 00:07:54.948
And when I select properties here,
I can then come down here and

147
00:07:54.948 --> 00:07:58.601
select configure directory partitions.

148
00:07:58.601 --> 00:08:01.477
And verify that I have
these directory partitions.

149
00:08:01.477 --> 00:08:05.325
Now, mine here only has
a single one that's available,

150
00:08:05.325 --> 00:08:10.215
so that's the only one that I have,
but at this point, once I have that,

151
00:08:10.215 --> 00:08:13.341
if I had multiple ones,
I can simply uncheck or

152
00:08:13.341 --> 00:08:17.300
check the ones that I want to
actually to be able to sync up.

153
00:08:17.300 --> 00:08:19.570
So, I can do something
like that if I choose to.

154
00:08:19.570 --> 00:08:23.600
Now, the other option is also down here
where it says select containers for

155
00:08:23.600 --> 00:08:27.280
this partition, as well and
we'll actually see that there.

156
00:08:27.280 --> 00:08:30.000
And then you have to enter in
your credentials there, okay?

157
00:08:30.000 --> 00:08:32.850
So just kinda realize that that's
the way that we can do it for

158
00:08:32.850 --> 00:08:36.700
the actual domain if we were to
do something like this, as well.

159
00:08:36.700 --> 00:08:38.510
Now, if you make any changes,

160
00:08:38.510 --> 00:08:41.220
the problem that you have is
that this is a two-part thing.

161
00:08:41.220 --> 00:08:44.980
And this is where a lot of people
kind of get lost in this, right?

162
00:08:44.980 --> 00:08:48.170
So I'm gonna leave this thing checked but
then show you the second part.

163
00:08:48.170 --> 00:08:50.200
If you make a change there,
in other words you go look,

164
00:08:50.200 --> 00:08:53.030
I don't want the ITProTVdemo.com,

165
00:08:53.030 --> 00:08:59.800
I want the lab.ITProTV domain
instead that I want to sync up here.

166
00:08:59.800 --> 00:09:01.490
Well, after you actually select that and

167
00:09:01.490 --> 00:09:05.250
you make that change, it's from there
you have to actually go back in and

168
00:09:05.250 --> 00:09:07.930
let me be sure I'm telling
you right at this point here.

169
00:09:07.930 --> 00:09:11.540
You have to actually check
a run profile as well.

170
00:09:11.540 --> 00:09:13.430
So, let me do that too.

171
00:09:13.430 --> 00:09:16.540
So notice that I have
the action that says run, and

172
00:09:16.540 --> 00:09:19.600
so there it is,
the run connector that I have, and

173
00:09:19.600 --> 00:09:24.270
these are different profiles that we
actually have set up and in place.

174
00:09:24.270 --> 00:09:29.270
So if you modify you also have to verify
what you want to modify from here, okay.

175
00:09:29.270 --> 00:09:33.210
So do you want to actually do a full
import out of that active directory?

176
00:09:33.210 --> 00:09:36.681
So if we choose lab.ITProTV or

177
00:09:36.681 --> 00:09:41.540
ITPro.TV, we would select that,
we'd do that full import, and

178
00:09:41.540 --> 00:09:44.485
that would actually be getting
that synchronization process.

179
00:09:44.485 --> 00:09:48.360
Notice you can actually just do
the full synchronization instead.

180
00:09:48.360 --> 00:09:49.720

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel take you through setting up the Azure Active Directory Sync(AADSync) Tool. They begin by revisiting some of the best practices and pre-planning steps that you'll need to complete as well as covering a list of prerequisites that are necessary for running AADSync; all while starting the AADSync Tool install and deployment.

00:26:56.092 --> 00:26:58.765
accounts in here, and
Ronny you haven't assigned anything.

470
00:26:58.765 --> 00:27:02.501
So now, what it's doing is going
through and it's doing a lot more,

471
00:27:02.501 --> 00:27:04.450
health mail box checks here.

472
00:27:04.450 --> 00:27:08.200
And that is because active directory
is now starting to send messages,

473
00:27:08.200 --> 00:27:11.650
about the health of the relationship of
all the things that are going on, for

474
00:27:11.650 --> 00:27:13.400
every single account that we have.

475
00:27:13.400 --> 00:27:16.630
So we're starting to see some
of that synchronization, and

476
00:27:16.630 --> 00:27:19.140
starting to do a lot more

477
00:27:19.140 --> 00:27:21.180
So it's just really here

478
00:27:21.180 --> 00:27:23.210
of getting that synchronization happening.

479
00:27:23.210 --> 00:27:26.790
Like I said, wait another 10 or
15 minutes, we may see everything kind

480
00:27:26.790 --> 00:27:30.440
of populate in, and you just fill in
unless I filled in the wrong field.

481
00:27:30.440 --> 00:27:31.902
That could also have happened too.

482
00:27:31.902 --> 00:27:36.817
So there's a lot of little things that we
need to keep track of if we're to do that,

483
00:27:36.817 --> 00:27:39.330
and that's pretty much the key, right?

484
00:27:39.330 --> 00:27:43.686
Is you go in and you make changes in your
on premises active directory, wait for

485
00:27:43.686 --> 00:27:48.174
those changes or try and force to change,
and then give it several minutes, go to

486
00:27:48.174 --> 00:27:53.170
Office 365, verify that those changes
have taken place, and there you have it.

487
00:27:53.170 --> 00:27:55.510
You gotta go back and
see what then synchronized, and

488
00:27:55.510 --> 00:27:58.310
that's just part of the troubleshooting
steps that we all have to be able to do.

489
00:27:58.310 --> 00:28:02.020
>> Yeah just part of being in the biz,
being sysadmin.

490
00:28:02.020 --> 00:28:03.060
Paste it across your chest.

491
00:28:03.060 --> 00:28:05.025
These are the kinds of things that
you're gonna have to go through.

492
00:28:05.025 --> 00:28:06.690
Cuz like Ronnie said it's easy for
me to go,

493
00:28:06.690 --> 00:28:09.540
oh I actually put that in the wrong field,
let me go back and do that.

494
00:28:09.540 --> 00:28:10.750
And you could have swore,

495
00:28:10.750 --> 00:28:13.800
you would have bet your life on the farm,
that you put the right thing in.

496
00:28:13.800 --> 00:28:17.250
You go back, oh yeah I put it in the wrong
field, and now it's starting to show,

497
00:28:17.250 --> 00:28:18.890
we have to resync it again.

498
00:28:18.890 --> 00:28:20.330
But, the cool thing is,

499
00:28:20.330 --> 00:28:24.980
is that if we do need that on demand sync,
CLI comes around right to our rescue.

500
00:28:24.980 --> 00:28:27.310
We do have a tool that
will allow us to do that.

501
00:28:27.310 --> 00:28:30.320
And those are the kind of things that
you're probably gonna get embedded into

502
00:28:30.320 --> 00:28:33.850
your brain because you're gonna do often
enough that you're gonna remember it.

503
00:28:33.850 --> 00:28:37.040
All right,
it's gonna become a part of what you do

504
00:28:37.040 --> 00:28:38.570
when you need to do an on demand sync.

505
00:28:38.570 --> 00:28:40.980
Oh, not a problem,
I know the tool to go to.

506
00:28:40.980 --> 00:28:43.870
And Ronnie, is there anything else
that we need to understand or

507
00:28:43.870 --> 00:28:45.280
know as far as this class goes?

508
00:28:45.280 --> 00:28:48.280
>> No,
right now at least getting it started and

509
00:28:48.280 --> 00:28:51.810
getting the initial synchronization
happening is pretty much the key.

510
00:28:51.810 --> 00:28:53.410
And then, of course, going back and

511
00:28:53.410 --> 00:28:56.640
verifying the sync's happening, and if you

512
00:28:56.640 --> 00:28:59.020
this is where you go back and
go, what did I check here?

513
00:28:59.020 --> 00:29:01.990
If I'm starting to see accounts here that
I didn't, it meant that one of my filters

514
00:29:01.990 --> 00:29:05.310
didn't work or I forgot to filter
something I should've, and

515
00:29:05.310 --> 00:29:09.610
that goes back then to your on premises
active directory, resetting those filters,

516
00:29:09.610 --> 00:29:11.880
and forcing the synchronization again.

517
00:29:11.880 --> 00:29:14.330
So it is a learning process in that sense,

518
00:29:14.330 --> 00:29:18.100
where you do have to kind of try it out,
but at least you're here.

519
00:29:18.100 --> 00:29:21.771
And now your 500 users in the active

00:29:21.771 --> 00:29:22.473

521
00:29:22.473 --> 00:29:26.022
And the other thing that I,
there was one other thing that I remember,

522
00:29:26.022 --> 00:29:27.707
remember when I told you is that,

523
00:29:27.707 --> 00:29:31.979
if you this type of synchronization with
active directory, your users are not gonna

524
00:29:31.979 --> 00:29:36.271
automatically be assigned one of those
activation's right for the Office 365.

525
00:29:36.271 --> 00:29:40.698
That means each one of these is that users
that you actually assigned, you need to go

526
00:29:40.698 --> 00:29:45.180
back in and click on that licensing,
and actually assign the proper license.

527
00:29:45.180 --> 00:29:47.740
You may find out that not every
user's gonna have that, but

528
00:29:47.740 --> 00:29:51.160
if you are that means you paid for
additional licenses as well.

529
00:29:51.160 --> 00:29:51.940
>> All right, awesome.

530
00:29:51.940 --> 00:29:55.540
Great stuff, Ronnie, and it's gonna be
a benefit to anybody out there that's even

531
00:29:55.540 --> 00:29:59.380
thinking about deploying a Office 365

532
00:29:59.380 --> 00:30:02.240
That is the kind of stuff that
you absolutely must know.

533
00:30:02.240 --> 00:30:05.390
Or, if you're studying for an exam, which
you probably are if you're watching this

534
00:30:05.390 --> 00:30:08.170
episode here, then that's gonna
help you out there as well.

535
00:30:08.170 --> 00:30:10.310
Thank you so much Ronnie for
explaining this for us.

536
00:30:10.310 --> 00:30:11.739
And thank you for watching.

537
00:30:11.739 --> 00:30:14.235
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

538
00:30:14.235 --> 00:30:15.499
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

539
00:30:15.499 --> 00:30:16.359
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

540
00:30:16.359 --> 00:30:17.636
>> And we'll see you next time.

541
00:30:17.636 --> 00:30:23.180
[MUSIC]

topics.title: Implement and manage identities by using Azure Active Directory Synchronization (AADSync)

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes discuss planning and requirements necessary to set up a single sign on (SSO) implementation in Office 365. They look at scenarios in which a company might what to consider using an SSO. They explore federated identities, delegated users as well federated services to support single sign on.
episodes.title: Plan for Office365 SSO
episodes.transcript:

[MUSIC]

Welcome back to another exciting episode

And in this episode, we're gonna be

Let me get out of that purchase thing

So, it actually does take a bit of time

There are still certain ones which says

Well Office 365 in the past has

00:07:46.440 --> 00:07:48.722
>> So the concept,

is what I'm thinking of,

Now this is a little bit different because

00:07:58.988 --> 00:08:01.879
care of let's say an organizational unit-

Planning, like things

>> You definitely will need to

00:33:10.675 --> 00:33:14.404
So it really is about the load that we're
actually sending across all ready, in

But remember that it's the performance

00:33:21.985 --> 00:33:25.750
anything, back into your network,
especially if all your network users

596
00:33:25.750 --> 00:33:29.286

they're all connecting to Office 365.

00:33:29.286 --> 00:33:32.982
It can be a pretty intensive bit of

You can flood that pretty heavily,

especially if you're gonna be doing

00:34:01.749 --> 00:34:07.720

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take you step-by-step through installing and managing Active Directory Federated Services(ADFS) servers. They begin by creating an ADFS service account as well as install the Federation Services server role and supporting services like IIS and the .NET framework. They also show you how to install the necessary SSL certificate into IIS. Next they configure ADFS for Single Sign-On. Finally, they finish the setup by configuring Windows Azure Active Directory(WAAD) to connect to the Office365 environment.
episodes.title: Install ADFS for Office365

ITProTVdemo.com.

[LAUGH]

This is a very important

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their explanation and demonstration of implementing and managing Federated Identities for Single Sign-On. Now that all the leg-work is done, they move into verification of service using the PowerShell and Event Viewer as well as the Office365 Portal.
episodes.title: Install ADFS for Office365 Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike begin the process of setting up an Active Directory Federation Services proxy server to provide an SSO solution from outside the organization. They discuss and demonstrate configuring the prerequisites needed to set up an ADFS proxy, including creating DNS records, installing the role, modifying the HOSTS file, and configuring the necessary certificates.

The only other thing t I like is

Which means it's gonna actually also

00:26:39.176 --> 00:26:42.530
Now I've all ready done this, so that's

But let me go back now to

I'll show you I actually exported

So normally when you actually export it,

And then, you're gonna import that entire

502
00:27:16.580 --> 00:27:17.940
Once again, I all ready finished this, but

let me show you kind of

00:27:20.670 --> 00:27:25.920
Now on this one, if you're not sure what

Same location computer account,

Right click in the white area,

00:27:53.550 --> 00:27:57.180
Okay, so you wanna make sure that you

Now I have another certificate right

>> Fantastic Ronny and

Getting this setup, making sure that

There's a key part of this,

These are the things that you have to

So you've gotta go through that list,

making sure they're there, and

the next step then would be to actually

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue setting up an Active Directory Federation Services proxy server to provide an SSO solution from outside the organization. They walk through the configuration wizard for the proxy server, pointing out some common pitfalls. Then they confirm successful configuration using event viewer. They finish by testing connectivity from outside the organization.
episodes.title: Install SSO Proxy Server Part 2

11

How's it going Ronnie?

>> It's going well today.

13

As we continue to take a look.

14
00:00:43.590 --> 00:00:46.290
As setting up this real
final piece to the puzzle,

15

of everything we're doing with the active
directory federation services.

16
00:00:50.250 --> 00:00:54.260
Remember that when we're setting something

17
00:00:54.260 --> 00:00:57.780
is so that people on the outside
of our network boundary, right, so

00:00:57.780 --> 00:00:59.430
no longer within our building,

no longer being covered by the security

But on the outside, and they still

As well as on the cloud setting up this

particular proxy server is

So that what we end up doing of

A single set of credentials that

26

But also to the resources that
exist up in the cloud for us and

27

that is really a key component, right?

So, the good thing is we can leverage all

If we previously set up that active

we're only adding in that final

So let's go ahead and take a look here as

set up for us here, so that we can just
take a look at just a little bit closer

here for a moment and that way we have

36
00:02:02.450 --> 00:02:03.140
Okay?

37

So, the existing
infrastructure that I had.

00:02:05.630 --> 00:02:09.450
Of course is I've had a Office 365

From there I also has my domain

And it really consists of two servers.

And a couple of clients.

Okay, so inside of that structure

connected into Office 365, we set up that

We installed the active directory
federation services role,

we verified that once that was actually
connected the way that it needed to

that people inside of my network
could hit that federation server.

48
00:02:44.370 --> 00:02:45.210
That's perfectly fine.

49

And you might be wondering okay,

50

Well, it's right then that

51

they present their On Premises

they can actually use the,
what looks like the email address.

I know it's called a UPN name.

>> But it looks like an email address,

And it authenticates against that

When the DC05 validates that,

57
00:03:08.440 --> 00:03:11.870
it allows of course then access to

58

But now, when somebody on the inside of

In theory what should happen,

It's a claim that Office 365 will

That means that there

That Office 365 recognizes and

00:03:51.770 --> 00:03:54.170
But this is something we

If people, or actually tele-commuters,

The actual Internet where Office 365 and
Hover.com is,

72
00:04:07.150 --> 00:04:11.160
I don't want them coming internally

Because if I do that, right,
they're already in my network.

74
00:04:14.350 --> 00:04:15.470
That's not good.

75

So what we're doing instead,
is that we set up that proxy server.

76
00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:22.830
The proxy server is going to
be on a sub-net of its own, so

77

when they actually do authenticate it's
going to send it over to the proxy server.

78
00:04:27.070 --> 00:04:29.780
The proxy server then has to communicate.

79
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:33.510
Over to the federation server for
that process to continue.

80
00:04:33.510 --> 00:04:35.900
So it really is for us here.

81
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:39.930
The ability to ensure that outside
users can get the same connectivity and

82
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:42.820
use the same credentials
as those on the inside.

83
00:04:42.820 --> 00:04:43.410
>> Very nice.
So

84
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:46.920
it keeps our infrastructure safe is really
what it's about because we don't want to

85
00:04:46.920 --> 00:04:48.920
expose that federation server and

86
00:04:48.920 --> 00:04:52.990
that domain controller directly to
the Internet because yes, it would work.

87
00:04:52.990 --> 00:04:56.800
It will allow our users to have that
SSO capability when they're outside

88
00:04:56.800 --> 00:05:02.410
the network, but it also means the
potential for bad people to connect to it.

89
00:05:02.410 --> 00:05:06.460
Because we've had to open up the firewall
and say, yes traffic's allowed to come

90
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:09.010
in to my network and
talk to this Federation server.

91
00:05:09.010 --> 00:05:11.850
For this, the main controller, that's
where their proxy is the middleman, right?

92
00:05:11.850 --> 00:05:16.970
Proxy on behalf of, we'll let
the outside world talk to the proxy and

93
00:05:16.970 --> 00:05:20.020
then we'll let the proxy talk

94
00:05:20.020 --> 00:05:22.360
the domain controller that
are inside the network.

95
00:05:22.360 --> 00:05:25.740
That gives us layers of security, so

96
00:05:25.740 --> 00:05:29.230
we don't have to expose everything
directly to the public network.

97
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:30.650
>> That's a great way to think about it,

98
00:05:30.650 --> 00:05:34.180
right, is to keep clear about
why we need this proxy.

99
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:35.120
Can you do it the other way?

100
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:37.330
Yes.
But would you ever do it the other way?

101
00:05:37.330 --> 00:05:39.930
Well, you shouldn't is
what it comes down to.

102
00:05:39.930 --> 00:05:40.640
So just remember that.

103
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:44.110
And we also, in a previous episode,

essentially the things that have to be

105

And if you haven't seen that episode,
I do ask that you go back and

Because without that just saying
I know how to install a roll or

I know how to do this, don't get me wrong

then you go, why isn't it working?

110

Well, it does take a few components and
getting things set up

00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:11.670
unlike your public DNS registrar, as well
as getting that public IP address and

112
00:06:11.670 --> 00:06:13.590
getting that set up
the way it needs to be.

113
00:06:13.590 --> 00:06:16.700
Making sure that everything is actually
working there on the basic networking

114
00:06:16.700 --> 00:06:17.890
level as well.

115
00:06:17.890 --> 00:06:19.970
And from that point then you can go and

116
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:23.290
see that in this episode we're

117
00:06:23.290 --> 00:06:27.170
So the good thing is Mike we've

I'm not gonna be able to

our web application proxy for
single sign on.

610
00:31:47.550 --> 00:31:49.343
And to Office 365.

611
00:31:49.343 --> 00:31:52.080
>> Fantastic Ronnie,
that was a great demonstration there.

612
00:31:52.080 --> 00:31:56.140
There's a lot of steps involved getting
all the pre reqs, getting everything

613
00:31:56.140 --> 00:32:01.120
installed, and then getting it configured
properly, and then finally testing it out.

614
00:32:01.120 --> 00:32:04.860
So thanks Ronnie for
that great demo on setting up that SSO.

615
00:32:04.860 --> 00:32:07.870
Now we've got SSO inside our network.

616
00:32:07.870 --> 00:32:09.020
People can come into work.

617
00:32:09.020 --> 00:32:09.950
They sign on once.

618
00:32:09.950 --> 00:32:13.090
They can access all the resources,
their Office 365.

619
00:32:13.090 --> 00:32:17.110
Now they can even do it while they're
out on the road, when they're traveling,

620
00:32:17.110 --> 00:32:20.480
when they're at home, if they're
telecommuters, whatever the case may be.

621
00:32:20.480 --> 00:32:23.990
They can also take advantage of that
single sign-on and not be prompted for

622
00:32:23.990 --> 00:32:26.970
credentials, every time they
connect to a different service.

623
00:32:26.970 --> 00:32:28.470
That's fantastic, thanks for that Ronnie.

624
00:32:28.470 --> 00:32:29.960
Anything else you need to add?

625
00:32:29.960 --> 00:32:33.820
>> Just remember that even though
this is kind of the end on the

626
00:32:35.330 --> 00:32:37.090
>> Proxy servers and things like that.

627
00:32:37.090 --> 00:32:38.880
There is still a little bit more for

628
00:32:38.880 --> 00:32:41.370
us to go, but we're out of time, so
>> Okay.

629
00:32:41.370 --> 00:32:42.750
>> We'll hit that another episode.

630
00:32:42.750 --> 00:32:43.890
>> Very good, we'll save it for later.

631
00:32:43.890 --> 00:32:45.910
So that means you and I are coming back.

632
00:32:45.910 --> 00:32:48.240
Alright, thanks everybody for
watching, we hope you enjoyed,

633
00:32:48.240 --> 00:32:50.560
signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick
>> And I'm Ronnie Wang.

634
00:32:50.560 --> 00:32:51.809
>> And we'll see you next time.

635
00:32:51.809 --> 00:32:58.017
[MUSIC]

topics.title: Implement and manage federated identities for single sign-on (SSO)

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike demonstrate several ways to monitor and troubleshoot Office 365 availability and usage. They look at several tools available through the admin portal of Office 365. They show the various reports available in Office 365. Then they look at some additional tools available from Microsoft to help troubleshoot Office 365 availability.
episodes.title: Monitoring Office365
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.296 --> 00:00:10.296
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.211 --> 00:00:15.921
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.921 --> 00:00:17.274
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.274 --> 00:00:20.288
Today we're doing our Office 365 episodes.

5
00:00:20.288 --> 00:00:23.900
And specifically, in this one
we're gonna look at monitoring and

6

7

Not that anything would every
go wrong with Office 365,

8

no, in all seriousness,
it's a very complex thing.

9
00:00:32.510 --> 00:00:35.960
We're dealing with our local network
with connectivity out to the cloud,

10
00:00:35.960 --> 00:00:39.170
with users inside,
with users Outside our network.

11
00:00:39.170 --> 00:00:41.390
So there is a lot of moving parts to it.

12
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:44.370
It's very important that we
understand how to monitor that.

13
00:00:44.370 --> 00:00:47.660
How to make sure that
everybody remains connected or

14
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:50.000
can get connected when they need to.

15
00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:53.140
Here to help us with that and show us
a whole bunch of cool tools we can use to

16
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:56.270
monitor Office 365 is the one and
only Ronnie Wong.

17
00:00:56.270 --> 00:00:57.090
How you doing Ronnie?

18
00:00:57.090 --> 00:00:58.470
>> I'm doing fine.

19
00:00:58.470 --> 00:01:01.498
Here we are.
We're at this point inside of our Office

20
00:01:01.498 --> 00:01:06.155
365 series where we do need to take
a look at some of the tools that

21
00:01:06.155 --> 00:01:11.004
are available for us to be able to
monitor the usage of Office 365.

22
00:01:11.004 --> 00:01:15.764
It wasn't actually so long ago,
actually as of the filming of this

23
00:01:15.764 --> 00:01:20.269
particular show it was just a couple
of days ago, one of the most

24
00:01:20.269 --> 00:01:25.690
popular uses of the development hubs,
GitHub, went down for hours.

25
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:28.160
Okay, it went down for hours by itself.

26
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:31.730
There were a couple of other events during
that week that also ended up happening,

27
00:01:31.730 --> 00:01:34.720
and even during the recording
of this particular show,

28
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:38.280
a couple of weeks ago, you know, or maybe
a little bit longer ago, I can't remember.

29
00:01:39.290 --> 00:01:43.020
Office365 itself went down okay.

30
00:01:43.020 --> 00:01:48.170
So you name it, there's always gonna be
some issues that you tend to not have

31
00:01:48.170 --> 00:01:52.970
needed to ever think about when you're
only dealing with on premises things.

32
00:01:52.970 --> 00:01:56.130
Where now when you are connected

33
00:01:56.130 --> 00:02:01.060
you need to know that there are ways that
you can at least monitor what's going on.

34
00:02:01.060 --> 00:02:04.240
There's also gonna be ways
that you can also troubleshoot

35
00:02:04.240 --> 00:02:06.950
a lot of the usage that you're
gonna have with Office 365.

36
00:02:06.950 --> 00:02:09.250
So, you can guarantee,

37
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:14.350
at least at your end, where you check up
on everything and everything is good.

38
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:18.040
But how is it that you now go and
connect into the cloud and

39
00:02:18.040 --> 00:02:22.530
go well, I don't know there's
a problem between here and

40
00:02:22.530 --> 00:02:27.860
Office 365 now anywhere along that
path depending on where you are right?

41
00:02:27.860 --> 00:02:32.720
Or is it actually a problem
over at Office 365 as well?

42
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:36.360
Well the good thing is those guys over
there at Microsoft when they developed

43
00:02:36.360 --> 00:02:40.060
Office 365 they knew that this

44

You troubleshoot everything on your

45
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:46.930
And they would probably look at their
end and go, no, our end's fine.

46
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:48.380
So it's gotta be somewhere in between.

47
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:52.640
And you don't really have any recourse
on that the majority of the time,

48
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:54.130
you just have to kinda wait it out.

49
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:56.600
And you can do a little bit of snooping,
right.

50
00:02:56.600 --> 00:03:01.130
To try and figure out where places
along the backbone, the connection

51
00:03:01.130 --> 00:03:05.940
between you and Office 365 have

52
00:03:05.940 --> 00:03:06.680
But what do you do?
You

53
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:09.630
just have to wait until that clears up and

54

But the good thing is, like I said,
what you're going to end up seeing here

in Office 365 though,

00:03:19.810 --> 00:03:21.680
that way,
if everything on your end is fine,

58

59

So, I'm gonna actually on my machine,

there's a couple of different things

that will work better on

all the tools that Office tends to

And then even though I'm on a Mac
computer, it's not gonna be for a Mac.

65
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:48.460
It's usually gonna be for
a Windows based computer.

66
00:03:48.460 --> 00:03:51.410
So if you want to take advantage
of the full functionality of

67
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:56.340
everything that Microsoft Office 365
gives you, that's what you want to be on.

68
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:58.260
And there's nothing I

69

More than likely, you're probably

70

As much as you may love Mac computers,

gonna redevelop a troubleshooting tool

00:04:10.480 --> 00:04:14.120
And they may add one in there

00:04:14.120 --> 00:04:17.130
the primary focus of course

So what you're seeing right here in

00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:23.230
Microsoft Office 365, right?

So when you go in there, if you log in as

that you actually go over to

And select the admin tile, or button.

Whatever they want to call it today.

80

And make sure that you get into

00:04:39.960 --> 00:04:41.750
Now once you're in the admin console,

82
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:46.120
you really don't have to navigate

00:04:46.120 --> 00:04:48.210
And you'll see that on this

00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:50.610
I'm just gonna scroll down

00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:55.230
Now let me see if I can zoom in just

00:04:55.230 --> 00:04:59.200
You'll see that there's a service

And so this is key.

If you are actually going to be suspecting

00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:12.440
Okay.
If you can get to their site

00:05:12.440 --> 00:05:14.890
you at least have partial functionality.

But notice the list here, and

00:05:16.520 --> 00:05:19.790
there's actually marks right here

Hopefully, the majority of the time,

00:05:27.340 --> 00:05:28.910
Mike, you and I have talked about this.

One of the colors that we love, especially

Green is good, right?

there's actually not gonna

In other words that probably

Now if you're like other people right,

You don't care or

Notice over here there's

So on each one of the services that

In other words you can actually

Office 365 gives you the service help and

Azure Active Directory but

Subscription services, if you want

I guarantee you if there's any one

You can't do anything.

They still want you to be

00:06:58.130 --> 00:06:59.250
It makes sense for them.

And of course there's Rights Management.

Share Point if you're gonna

Skype for Business,

Your own personal kind of Facebook for

00:07:10.330 --> 00:07:11.120
You wanna do that.

131
00:07:11.120 --> 00:07:15.210
Right now nothing is actually showing

132
00:07:15.210 --> 00:07:17.970
And that is a good day.

00:07:17.970 --> 00:07:22.910
So when you take a look at monitoring,

>> So this is showing me on

So, again, going back to what you

Is it on their end?

This is helping indicate that

that means the trouble lies

00:07:50.712 --> 00:07:54.710

00:07:59.033 --> 00:08:02.868
If it's on my end, I just go to a machine

00:08:06.070 --> 00:08:09.470
Office 365 is reporting that they're good,

152
00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:18.410
see if we can still connect, and if we
still can't connect, there probably is

153
00:08:18.410 --> 00:08:22.190
gonna be some type of connectivity

154
00:08:22.190 --> 00:08:24.060
Now, before we're actually done with this,

even though that's actually a very

156
00:08:28.090 --> 00:08:30.200
So let's go back and take a look here.

00:08:30.200 --> 00:08:34.400
As we see that there's actually a nice,

Which is View Details and
History and I'm gonna try and oop.

00:08:37.490 --> 00:08:37.990
Let me see.

00:08:37.990 --> 00:08:40.940
I'm not sure if I could zoom in and

And I'll zoom back out just for

00:08:46.570 --> 00:08:52.225
So, even though I get a nice, graphical
representation of a summary of things,

00:08:52.225 --> 00:08:55.550
I just wanna make sure try and
get this big enough so we can see,

164
00:08:55.550 --> 00:08:59.570
just a little bit here, and I'm gonna go,
and, yeah, zoom in like that.

165
00:08:59.570 --> 00:09:00.210
Okay?

166
00:09:00.210 --> 00:09:04.490
So, notice that I can see it from the top,
they, they now have it, alphabetically,

00:09:04.490 --> 00:09:06.310
I was trying to make sure I said it right.

00:09:06.310 --> 00:09:09.220
So, exchange online is at top,
identity service,

169
00:09:09.220 --> 00:09:12.460
mobile device manager,
office portal You name it.

170
00:09:12.460 --> 00:09:16.260
You can see that it actually gives you
about a week's time period there, right?

171
00:09:16.260 --> 00:09:20.730
Seven days of how the operational
service health is.

172
00:09:20.730 --> 00:09:25.070
And I can tell you that sometime
on January 23rd and 24th, and

173
00:09:25.070 --> 00:09:28.980
if I hover over it notice that it
actually gives me another link

174
00:09:28.980 --> 00:09:31.990
that tells me something else may
have actually occurred there.

175
00:09:31.990 --> 00:09:35.930
So I know that email and calendar access,
if I click on that link,

176
00:09:35.930 --> 00:09:40.670
it will then come down and
give me much more detailed status.

177
00:09:40.670 --> 00:09:45.050
So if you were experiencing issues or
if you really did need to track that, and

178
00:09:45.050 --> 00:09:47.160
you go, I didn't have time to look at it,

179
00:09:47.160 --> 00:09:50.990
you have at least a week's worth of
logs that you can go back in and go.

180
00:09:50.990 --> 00:09:52.000
I do remember that.

181
00:09:52.000 --> 00:09:55.840
I do remember that Office 365
was having an issue here.

182
00:09:55.840 --> 00:09:59.110
And so it does give you much
more detailed information.

183
00:09:59.110 --> 00:10:00.200
Which is really nice.

184
00:10:00.200 --> 00:10:01.020
>> That's fantastic.

185
00:10:01.020 --> 00:10:04.730
So if a user, especially like a remote
user that's not normally in the office,

186
00:10:04.730 --> 00:10:06.880
comes in on a Friday, and says hey look,

187
00:10:06.880 --> 00:10:11.680
last Tuesday I was having trouble

188
00:10:11.680 --> 00:10:13.060
What's going on?

189
00:10:13.060 --> 00:10:16.100
I didn't look because, I didn't know
there was a problem, right, and

00:10:16.100 --> 00:10:18.420
I can go see that history and I can say,

191
00:10:18.420 --> 00:10:22.720
Tuesday they were experiencing an outage,
that's probably what the problem was.

192
00:10:22.720 --> 00:10:24.598
>> It really is and its a little bit more,

193
00:10:24.598 --> 00:10:28.002
so I kind of zoomed over some of
the details but I want to show you kind of

00:10:28.002 --> 00:10:31.990
the breakdown of what you'll normally

195
00:10:31.990 --> 00:10:34.620
So the first thing that you
see up at the top here, again,

00:34:25.330 --> 00:34:26.901
>> Fantastic stuff, Ronnie.

646
00:34:26.901 --> 00:34:30.792
A lot of larger organizations and
small ones as well, but

647
00:34:30.792 --> 00:34:33.151
I see it mostly in the bigger ones.

648
00:34:33.151 --> 00:34:36.974
They really rely on that free and busy,
because I have got to get with certain

649
00:34:36.974 --> 00:34:39.985
people and they are in other locations,
other time zones.

650
00:34:39.985 --> 00:34:43.532
And I have got to be able to look at that
calendar, see if they are available for

651
00:34:43.532 --> 00:34:45.223
a conference call or what have you and

652
00:34:45.223 --> 00:34:49.010
we start spreading our environment out
to local and out there in the cloud.

653
00:34:49.010 --> 00:34:50.045
It gets pretty complex
trying to manage that.

654
00:34:50.045 --> 00:34:51.055
Fantastic.

655
00:34:51.055 --> 00:34:55.859
We had a good tool specifically
to troubleshoot that feature.

656
00:34:55.859 --> 00:34:56.628
Great look, Ronnie,

657
00:34:56.628 --> 00:34:58.901
at all the different trouble
shooting capabilities that we have.

658
00:34:58.901 --> 00:35:03.162
Monitoring as well as troubleshooting,
our Office 365 as well as a hybrid type

659
00:35:03.162 --> 00:35:06.436
environment where we've got
some of it running on-premise,

660
00:35:06.436 --> 00:35:08.185
some of it out there in the cloud.

661
00:35:08.185 --> 00:35:10.360
We appreciate that, great examples.

662
00:35:10.360 --> 00:35:13.809
Hope everybody out there enjoyed this
episode, that's going to do it for

663
00:35:13.809 --> 00:35:14.317
this one.

664
00:35:14.317 --> 00:35:16.190
Signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

665
00:35:16.190 --> 00:35:17.283
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

666
00:35:17.283 --> 00:35:20.276
>> And we'll see you next time.

667
00:35:20.276 --> 00:35:20.776
[MUSIC]
